1. 1 Introduction
  2. 2 A stochastic approach in projectile motion
  3. 3 A stochastic approach in statics
  4. 4 Concluding remarks
  5. A Basic knowledge of probability
  6. B Basic knowledge of mechanics

A stochastic approach in physics exercises of
mathematics education

Mátyás Barczy∗,⋄superscriptBarczy⋄\text{Barczy}^{*,\diamond}Barczy start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ , ⋄ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT,  Imre Kocsis∗∗superscriptKocsisabsent\text{Kocsis}^{**}Kocsis start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT,  Csaba Gábor Kézi∗∗superscriptKéziabsent\text{K\'{e}zi}^{**}Kézi start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT

* HUN-REN–SZTE Analysis and Applications Research Group, Bolyai Institute, University of Szeged, Aradi vértanúk tere 1, H–6720 Szeged, Hungary.

** Department of Basic Technical Studies, Faculty of Engineering, University of Debrecen, Ótemető utca 2-4, H–4028 Debrecen, Hungary.

E-mails: barczy@math.u-szeged.hu (M. Barczy), kezicsaba@eng.unideb.hu (Cs. G. Kézi),
kocsisi@eng.unideb.hu (I. Kocsis).

⋄⋄\diamond⋄ Corresponding author.

††2020 Mathematics Subject Classifications: 97K50, 97M50. ††Key words and phrases: projectile motion, statics, probability theory.
Abstract

We present a method for incorporating a stochastic point of view into physics exercises of mathematics education. The core of our method is the randomization of some inputs, the system model used does not differ from what we would use in the deterministic approach. We consider exercises from the theory of projectile motion and statics. The outputs of stochastic models are random variables, and we usually determine their probability distributions, expected values, variances, and relative standard deviations, and the probabilities of some events related to them are also calculated. We primarily recommend our exercises to motivated high school students but first-year university students can also benefit from them.

1 Introduction

Deterministic and stochastic models play equally significant roles in engineering sciences and economy. However, in many countries (for example, in Hungary) a deterministic approach is at the heart of education and thus of student thinking (in particular, at high schools).

The effect of uncontrolled input (noise) on the output of a system can be negligible, but it can also be very important and lead to false conclusions. In deterministic models, we make the simplifying assumption that there is no noise. Whether this simplification causes problems in solving a real-world problem depends on how much uncertainty there is in the system’s inputs and parameters, and how sensitive the output is to this uncertainty. If we do not examine this, then we cannot judge the adequacy of the solution resulting from the deterministic model. When solving a problem, a conscious choice must be made between deterministic and stochastic models. Didactically, the applicability of the two approaches is very different. A stochastic approach is usually unavoidable when analyzing problems in engineering sciences, economy and financial mathematics. The emphasis is on seeing the difference in the output (solution of the problem under study) for deterministic and random inputs. Studying the stochastic approach is important for understanding the phenomena and processes of everyday life. For example, we constantly evaluate risks and act according to our individual risk tolerance. A person who is not familiar with the concept of risk does not understand what to expect from an investment and is unable to deal with situations that do not correspond to his or her preconcept.

There is a long tradition of the illustration of the basic ideas and calculations of probability theory in teaching using gambling games. For example, we can mention the book of Schoenberg [7] in which both standard and advanced probability topics are illustrated using the popular poker game of Texas Hold’em, rather than the typical balls in urns. Johnson [3] has chosen the gambling game of Craps for such purposes.

In this article, we present a method for incorporating a stochastic point of view into physics exercises of mathematics education. The core of the method is the randomization of some inputs, the system model used does not differ from what we would use in the deterministic approach. In our exercises, the distribution of random inputs, in most of the cases, is a uniform distribution. This does not weaken the pedagogical goal, since using inputs with more complicated distributions would not make a difference in principle, it would only make the calculations more difficult. Of course, in real life problems, more general distributions such as exponential, normal or Pareto distributions could come into play. The outputs of stochastic models are random variables, and even if the inputs are uniformly distributed, the outputs are usually not uniformly distributed. We note that in Exercise 2.4 an absolutely continuous random variable with a given density function also appears for the ratio of the rebound and landing speeds when a tennis ball is dropped on concrete from a given distance. In the exercises, we usually determine the probability distributions, expected values, variances, and relative standard deviations of the outputs, and the probabilities of some events related to them are also calculated using the basic tools of probability theory.

We demonstrate our method of randomization of some inputs by considering exercises from the theory of projectile motion and statics. According to our knowledge, this stochastic viewpoint is not widespread for problems in projectile motion, and basically is not present at high schools and at physics competitions. Nonetheless, we can mention the research paper of Montecinos et al. [5] where an application of the maximum entropy inference to the problem of a two-dimensional projectile motion was investigated. Namely, given information about the average horizontal range over many realizations, they studied the problem of inferring the initial conditions, i.e., the initial angle and speed. In statics one can find several stochastic models. Here we only mention a recent paper of Cortés et al. [1] who carried out a probabilistic analysis of the deflection of a cantilever beam subjected to random loads via density functions.

Our reason for choosing the topics of projectile motion and statics for demonstrating our method is the fact that the physics behind these two topics is relatively easy to understand, and we would like to recommend our exercises to motivated high school students. Students learn the physics of projectile motion as early as the first years of high school. However, first-year university students can also benefit from getting acquainted with these exercises. Students may be asked to create similar exercises, for other fields of physics as well.

In Appendices A and B, we collected some of the basics of probability theory and mechanics that are needed to solve the problems, respectively. Most of the content of Appendix A on the required knowledge of probability theory is covered by the syllabus of high school students specialized in mathematics, except maybe the law of total expectation. Nonetheless, we remark that the law of total expectation is used only in the solution of part (ii) of Exercise 2.1 where an alternative solution using the method of geometric probability is also presented. The content of Appendix B on some knowledge of mechanics is essentially contained in the syllabus of high school students, and hence this appendix is not so detailed.

We take great care to demonstrate the use of the tools from probability theory, and hence we provide detailed solutions to the exercises. Our stochastic perspective can help the students recognize the fact that many phenomena in our daily lives have a random nature, and therefore it can be useful to get in touch with stochastic thinking and tools in order to be able to understand these phenomena much better.

The paper is structured as follows. Sections 2 and 3 are devoted to exercises for projectile motion and statics, respectively. In Sections 2 and 3, we present five and three exercises, respectively. We close the paper with Appendices A and B, where, without being exhaustive, we recall some of the notations, conventions, concepts and results of probability theory and mechanics that are used in solving the exercises.

Next, we briefly summarize what kind of tools in probability theory we use in the exercises of Sections 2 and 3. In Exercise 2.1, among others, we use the notions of expectation, variance and relative standard deviation of an absolutely continuous random variable, and we calculate the probability of an event by two methods, namely, by the method of geometric probability and by the law of total expectation, respectively. In part (iii) of Exercise 2.1, we calculate a conditional probability as well. In Exercise 2.2, we use the notions of expectation, variance and relative standard deviation of a discrete random variable, and the additivity property of probability. In Exercise 2.3, among others, the notion of the distribution of discrete and absolute continuous random variables and the notions of expectations, variances and relative standard deviations of such random variables come into play. In Exercise 2.4, we use the fact that a probability that an absolutely continuous random variable falls in a given interval can be calculated using the density function of the random variable in question, and we provide an application of Bayes’ theorem as well. In Exercise 2.5, we calculate the expected value of the relative error in some problems for free fall (i.e., for a motion of a body, where the gravity of Earth is the only force acting upon it) if instead of the precise value of the gravity of Earth we use an approximating random value for it. In this exercise, the notion of the expected value of an absolutely continuous random variable is used. In Exercises 3.2 and 3.3, 2-dimensional random variables and their expectation vectors play important roles.

The set of positive integers and real numbers is denoted by ℕℕ\mathbb{N}blackboard_N and ℝℝ\mathbb{R}blackboard_R, respectively. For a 2222-dimensional vector (x,y)∈ℝ2𝑥𝑦superscriptℝ2(x,y)\in\mathbb{R}^{2}( italic_x , italic_y ) ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, its Euclidean length is defined by ‖(x,y)‖:=x2+y2assignnorm𝑥𝑦superscript𝑥2superscript𝑦2\|(x,y)\|:=\sqrt{x^{2}+y^{2}}∥ ( italic_x , italic_y ) ∥ := square-root start_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG. The coordinates of a vector 𝒗𝒗{\boldsymbol{v}}bold_italic_v in the (x,y)𝑥𝑦(x,y)( italic_x , italic_y )-plane are denoted by vxsubscript𝑣𝑥v_{x}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and vysubscript𝑣𝑦v_{y}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively, i.e., 𝒗=(vx,vy)𝒗subscript𝑣𝑥subscript𝑣𝑦{\boldsymbol{v}}=(v_{x},v_{y})bold_italic_v = ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). In the solutions, the number of significant digits is chosen to be 4 (for example, instead of 21.28521.28521.28521.285, we write 21.2921.2921.2921.29, or instead of 0.0234560.0234560.0234560.023456, we write 0.023460.023460.023460.02346). All of the physical quantities are expressed in SI units, so we do not display the units in calculations. In the calculations, the magnitude of the gravitational acceleration near the Earth’s surface is assumed to be g=9.81𝑔9.81g=9.81\,italic_g = 9.81ms2msuperscripts2\mathrm{\frac{m}{s^{2}}}divide start_ARG roman_m end_ARG start_ARG roman_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG.

2 A stochastic approach in projectile motion

In this section, we demonstrate our method for incorporating a stochastic point of view into physics exercises of mathematics education by presenting exercises for projectile motion. In these ones, some of the initial values, namely, the initial height and/or velocity of a launched ball, are chosen randomly to make the problems more realistic. We usually choose a uniform distribution, but in Exercise 2.4 an absolutely continuous random variable with a given density function also comes into play for the ratio of the rebound and landing speeds when a tennis ball is dropped on concrete from a given distance. In all of the exercises, we suppose that the air resistance is negligible. Altogether, we present five problems in this section.

2.1 Exercise.

Let us consider a cylindrical-shape forest lookout with a radius of 10 meters and a height of 50 meters, which stands on horizontal ground. From the bottom of the forest lookout, Thomas goes up the spiral staircase. Thomas stops at a height hℎhitalic_h chosen according to a uniform distribution on the interval [0⁢m,50⁢m]0m50m[0\,\mathrm{m},50\,\mathrm{m}][ 0 roman_m , 50 roman_m ], and from the edge of the forest lookout he launches a ball with velocity v𝑣vitalic_v of which the magnitude is uniformly distributed on the interval [5⁢ms,15⁢ms]5ms15ms[5\,\mathrm{\frac{m}{s}},15\,\mathrm{\frac{m}{s}}][ 5 divide start_ARG roman_m end_ARG start_ARG roman_s end_ARG , 15 divide start_ARG roman_m end_ARG start_ARG roman_s end_ARG ], and its direction is perpendicular to the wall of the forest lookout. We suppose that hℎhitalic_h and v𝑣vitalic_v are independent.

  • (i)

    What is the expected value, variance and relative standard deviation of the distance of which the ball hits the ground from the wall of the forest lookout?

  • (ii)

    Suppose that the forest lookout is surrounded by an annulus-shape fence to which the top is horizontal. The two walls of the fence (inner and outer circles) are 10101010 meters and 10.510.510.510.5 meters from the wall of the forest lookout, respectively. The height of the fence is 2222 meters. On Figure 1, the plane section determined by the direction of the shot is shown, and only the part of the fence in the direction of the shot is plotted. What is the probability that the ball first hits one of the line segments B⁢C𝐵𝐶BCitalic_B italic_C and C⁢D𝐶𝐷CDitalic_C italic_D (see Figure 1), that is, the ball first hits the fence?

  • (iii)

    Suppose that the forest lookout is surrounded by the same annulus-shape fence described in part (ii). Further, suppose that the ball first hits the line segment A⁢B𝐴𝐵ABitalic_A italic_B (that is, the ball first hits the ground in front of the fence but misses it). What is the probability that Thomas launched the ball from lower than 10 meters?

Solution. It is known that if we launch a ball horizontally at height hℎhitalic_h with velocity v𝑣vitalic_v, then the total (horizontal) distance of the whole journey before the ball hits the ground is d:=2⁢hg⋅vassign𝑑⋅2ℎ𝑔𝑣d:=\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}\cdot vitalic_d := square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ italic_v. Further, if the ball takes a distance x𝑥xitalic_x horizontally, then it takes a vertical distance g2⁢v2⋅x2⋅𝑔2superscript𝑣2superscript𝑥2\frac{g}{2v^{2}}\cdot x^{2}divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ⋅ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, see Figure 2 as well:

By our assumptions, hℎhitalic_h is a uniformly distributed random variable on the interval [0,50]050[0,50][ 0 , 50 ], v𝑣vitalic_v is a uniformly distributed random variable on the interval [5,15]515[5,15][ 5 , 15 ], and furthermore, hℎhitalic_h and v𝑣vitalic_v are independent.

(i). Then hℎ\sqrt{h}square-root start_ARG italic_h end_ARG and v𝑣vitalic_v are also independent, hence, using the homogeneity of expectation (see (A.2)), we get that

=2g⋅150⋅2⋅503/23⋅110⋅152−522=2003⁢g≈21.29.absent⋅2𝑔150⋅2superscript50323110superscript152superscript5222003𝑔21.29\displaystyle=\sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}\cdot\frac{1}{50}\cdot\frac{2\cdot 50^{3/2}}{3% }\cdot\frac{1}{10}\cdot\frac{15^{2}-5^{2}}{2}=\frac{200}{3\sqrt{g}}\approx 21.% 29.= square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 2 ⋅ 50 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 10 end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 15 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG = divide start_ARG 200 end_ARG start_ARG 3 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ≈ 21.29 .

Now, we turn to calculate the variance and standard deviation of d𝑑ditalic_d. Using that hℎhitalic_h and v2superscript𝑣2v^{2}italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT are independent, we obtain that

𝔼⁡(d2)𝔼superscript𝑑2\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(d^{2})blackboard_E ( italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) =𝔼⁡((2⁢hg⋅v)2)=𝔼⁡(2⁢hg⋅v2)=2g⁢𝔼⁡(h)⋅𝔼⁡(v2)=2g⁢∫050p⋅150⁢dp⋅∫515r2⋅110⁢drabsent𝔼superscript⋅2ℎ𝑔𝑣2𝔼⋅2ℎ𝑔superscript𝑣2⋅2𝑔𝔼ℎ𝔼superscript𝑣22𝑔superscriptsubscript050⋅⋅𝑝150differential-d𝑝superscriptsubscript515⋅superscript𝑟2110differential-d𝑟\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left(\left(\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}\cdot v% \right)^{2}\right)=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left(\frac{2h}{g}\cdot v^{2}% \right)=\frac{2}{g}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(h)\cdot\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(% v^{2})=\frac{2}{g}\int_{0}^{50}p\cdot\frac{1}{50}\,\mathrm{d}p\cdot\int_{5}^{1% 5}r^{2}\cdot\frac{1}{10}\,\mathrm{d}r= blackboard_E ( ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ italic_v ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = blackboard_E ( divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ⋅ italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG blackboard_E ( italic_h ) ⋅ blackboard_E ( italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 50 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_p ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG roman_d italic_p ⋅ ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 15 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 10 end_ARG roman_d italic_r
=2g⋅150⋅25002⋅110⋅3375−1253=162503⁢g.absent⋅2𝑔1502500211033751253162503𝑔\displaystyle=\frac{2}{g}\cdot\frac{1}{50}\cdot\frac{2500}{2}\cdot\frac{1}{10}% \cdot\frac{3375-125}{3}=\frac{16250}{3g}.= divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 2500 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 10 end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 3375 - 125 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG = divide start_ARG 16250 end_ARG start_ARG 3 italic_g end_ARG .

Consequently, the variance of d𝑑ditalic_d takes the form

𝔻2⁡(d)=𝔼⁡(d2)−(𝔼⁡(d))2=162503⁢g−400009⁢g=87509⁢g≈99.11,superscript𝔻2𝑑𝔼superscript𝑑2superscript𝔼𝑑2162503𝑔400009𝑔87509𝑔99.11\operatorname{\mathbb{D}}^{2}(d)=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(d^{2})-(% \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(d))^{2}=\frac{16250}{3g}-\frac{40000}{9g}=\frac{8750% }{9g}\approx 99.11,blackboard_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_d ) = blackboard_E ( italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - ( blackboard_E ( italic_d ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 16250 end_ARG start_ARG 3 italic_g end_ARG - divide start_ARG 40000 end_ARG start_ARG 9 italic_g end_ARG = divide start_ARG 8750 end_ARG start_ARG 9 italic_g end_ARG ≈ 99.11 ,

and hence the standard deviation of d𝑑ditalic_d is

𝔻⁡(d)=25⁢143⁢g≈9.955.𝔻𝑑25143𝑔9.955\operatorname{\mathbb{D}}(d)=\frac{25\sqrt{14}}{3\sqrt{g}}\approx 9.955.blackboard_D ( italic_d ) = divide start_ARG 25 square-root start_ARG 14 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 3 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ≈ 9.955 .

This implies that the relative standard deviation of d𝑑ditalic_d is

RSD⁡(d)=25⁢143⁢g2003⁢g=148≈0.4677.RSD𝑑25143𝑔2003𝑔1480.4677\operatorname{RSD}(d)=\frac{\frac{25\sqrt{14}}{3\sqrt{g}}}{\frac{200}{3\sqrt{g% }}}=\frac{\sqrt{14}}{8}\approx 0.4677.roman_RSD ( italic_d ) = divide start_ARG divide start_ARG 25 square-root start_ARG 14 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 3 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG 200 end_ARG start_ARG 3 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG end_ARG = divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 14 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG ≈ 0.4677 .

(ii). Let us introduce the events R𝑅Ritalic_R and S𝑆Sitalic_S:

R:={the ball’s (first) point of impact is in the line segment A⁢B}={d<10},assign𝑅the ball’s (first) point of impact is in the line segment A⁢B𝑑10\displaystyle R:=\Big{\{}\text{the ball's (first) point of impact is in the % line segment $AB$}\Big{\}}=\Big{\{}d<10\Big{\}},italic_R := { the ball’s (first) point of impact is in the line segment italic_A italic_B } = { italic_d < 10 } ,
S:={the ball’s (first) point of impact is to the right of the point E}assign𝑆the ball’s (first) point of impact is to the right of the point E\displaystyle S:=\Big{\{}\text{the ball's (first) point of impact is to the % right of the point $E$}\Big{\}}italic_S := { the ball’s (first) point of impact is to the right of the point italic_E }
={g2⁢v2⋅10.52<h−2}.absent⋅𝑔2superscript𝑣2superscript10.52ℎ2\displaystyle\phantom{:=\,}=\Big{\{}\frac{g}{2v^{2}}\cdot 10.5^{2}<h-2\Big{\}}.= { divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ⋅ 10.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < italic_h - 2 } .

Then we get that

(2.1) ℙ⁡({the ball hits the fence before it hits the ground})=1−ℙ⁡(R)−ℙ⁡(S).ℙ{the ball hits the fence before it hits the ground}1ℙ𝑅ℙ𝑆\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\big{(}\text{\{the ball hits the fence % before it hits the ground\}}\big{)}=1-\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(R)-% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(S).blackboard_P ( {the ball hits the fence before it hits the ground} ) = 1 - blackboard_P ( italic_R ) - blackboard_P ( italic_S ) .

In what follows, we determine the probabilities ℙ⁡(R)ℙ𝑅\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(R)blackboard_P ( italic_R ) and ℙ⁡(S)ℙ𝑆\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(S)blackboard_P ( italic_S ) using two different methods: the method of geometric probabilities (Method 1) and the law of total expectation (Method 2).

Method 1 (geometric probabilities): By Figure 3

and the method of geometric probabilities we obtain that

ℙ⁡(R)ℙ𝑅\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(R)blackboard_P ( italic_R ) =ℙ⁡(d<10)=ℙ⁡(2⁢hg⋅v<10)=ℙ⁡(v<10⁢g2⋅1h)absentℙ𝑑10ℙ⋅2ℎ𝑔𝑣10ℙ𝑣⋅10𝑔21ℎ\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(d<10\right)=\operatorname{\mathbb% {P}}\left(\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}\cdot v<10\right)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(% v<\frac{10\sqrt{g}}{\sqrt{2}}\cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{h}}\right)= blackboard_P ( italic_d < 10 ) = blackboard_P ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ italic_v < 10 ) = blackboard_P ( italic_v < divide start_ARG 10 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_h end_ARG end_ARG )
=TR50⁢(15−5)=TR500,absentsubscript𝑇𝑅50155subscript𝑇𝑅500\displaystyle=\frac{T_{R}}{50(15-5)}=\frac{T_{R}}{500},= divide start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 50 ( 15 - 5 ) end_ARG = divide start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 500 end_ARG ,

where 500500500500 is the area of the rectangle [0,50]×[5,15]050515[0,50]\times[5,15][ 0 , 50 ] × [ 5 , 15 ] (”total” area), and the ”probable” area TRsubscript𝑇𝑅T_{R}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be calculated as follows. First, we determine the points at which the function (0,∞)∋h↦10⁢g2⋅1hcontains0ℎmaps-to⋅10𝑔21ℎ(0,\infty)\ni h\mapsto\frac{10\sqrt{g}}{\sqrt{2}}\cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{h}}( 0 , ∞ ) ∋ italic_h ↦ divide start_ARG 10 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_h end_ARG end_ARG takes the values 15151515 and 5555, respectively (see Figure 3). By algebraic calculations, we can get that

(2.2) the solution of the equation  10⁢g2⋅1h=15⋅10𝑔21ℎ15\frac{10\sqrt{g}}{\sqrt{2}}\cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{h}}=15divide start_ARG 10 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_h end_ARG end_ARG = 15, h>0ℎ0h>0italic_h > 0,  is  h=g2⋅1.52=2.18ℎ𝑔⋅2superscript1.522.18h=\frac{g}{2\cdot 1.5^{2}}=2.18italic_h = divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 ⋅ 1.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG = 2.18,

and

(2.3) the solution of the equation  10⁢g2⋅1h=5⋅10𝑔21ℎ5\frac{10\sqrt{g}}{\sqrt{2}}\cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{h}}=5divide start_ARG 10 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_h end_ARG end_ARG = 5, h>0ℎ0h>0italic_h > 0,  is  h=g2⋅0.52=19.62ℎ𝑔⋅2superscript0.5219.62h=\frac{g}{2\cdot 0.5^{2}}=19.62italic_h = divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 ⋅ 0.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG = 19.62.

Consequently, by splitting the area TRsubscript𝑇𝑅T_{R}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R end_POSTSUBSCRIPT into two parts, we have that

Then

Similarly, we obtain

ℙ⁡(S)=480−10.52⁢g15500=4850−110.25⁢g7500≈0.8158.ℙ𝑆480superscript10.52𝑔155004850110.25𝑔75000.8158\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(S)=\frac{480-\frac{10.5^{2}g}{15}}{500}=\frac{48}{50% }-\frac{110.25g}{7500}\approx 0.8158.blackboard_P ( italic_S ) = divide start_ARG 480 - divide start_ARG 10.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 15 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 500 end_ARG = divide start_ARG 48 end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 110.25 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 7500 end_ARG ≈ 0.8158 .

Method 2 (law of total expectation): Since v𝑣vitalic_v is uniformly distributed on the interval [5,15]515[5,15][ 5 , 15 ], its density function takes the form

fv⁢(r)={110if r∈[5,15],0otherwise.subscript𝑓𝑣𝑟cases110if r∈[5,15],0otherwise.f_{v}(r)=\begin{cases}\frac{1}{10}&\text{if \ $r\in[5,15]$,}\\ 0&\text{otherwise.}\end{cases}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) = { start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 10 end_ARG end_CELL start_CELL if italic_r ∈ [ 5 , 15 ] , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL otherwise. end_CELL end_ROW

Using the law of total expectation (see (A.4)) and the independence of hℎhitalic_h and v𝑣vitalic_v, we have that

ℙ⁡(R)ℙ𝑅\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(R)blackboard_P ( italic_R ) =ℙ⁡(d<10)=ℙ⁡(2⁢hg⋅v<10)=∫−∞∞ℙ⁡(2⁢hg⋅r<10)⁢fv⁢(r)⁢drabsentℙ𝑑10ℙ⋅2ℎ𝑔𝑣10superscriptsubscriptℙ⋅2ℎ𝑔𝑟10subscript𝑓𝑣𝑟differential-d𝑟\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(d<10)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(% \sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}\cdot v<10\right)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}\operatorname{% \mathbb{P}}\left(\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}\cdot r<10\right)f_{v}(r)\,\mathrm{d}r= blackboard_P ( italic_d < 10 ) = blackboard_P ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ italic_v < 10 ) = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ italic_r < 10 ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_v end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) roman_d italic_r
=∫515ℙ⁡(2⁢hg⋅r<10)⁢110⁢dr=110⁢∫515ℙ⁡(h<100⁢g2⋅1r2)⁢dr,absentsuperscriptsubscript515ℙ⋅2ℎ𝑔𝑟10110differential-d𝑟110superscriptsubscript515ℙℎ⋅100𝑔21superscript𝑟2differential-d𝑟\displaystyle=\int_{5}^{15}\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}% \cdot r<10\right)\frac{1}{10}\,\mathrm{d}r=\frac{1}{10}\int_{5}^{15}% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(h<\frac{100g}{2}\cdot\frac{1}{r^{2}}\right)\,% \mathrm{d}r,= ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 15 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ italic_r < 10 ) divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 10 end_ARG roman_d italic_r = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 10 end_ARG ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 15 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P ( italic_h < divide start_ARG 100 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) roman_d italic_r ,

where

ℙ⁡(h<100⁢g2⋅1r2)=150⁢min⁡(50,50⁢gr2)=150⋅50⁢gr2=gr2,r∈[5,15],formulae-sequenceℙℎ⋅100𝑔21superscript𝑟21505050𝑔superscript𝑟2⋅15050𝑔superscript𝑟2𝑔superscript𝑟2𝑟515\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(h<\frac{100g}{2}\cdot\frac{1}{r^{2}}\right)=% \frac{1}{50}\min\left(50,\frac{50g}{r^{2}}\right)=\frac{1}{50}\cdot\frac{50g}{% r^{2}}=\frac{g}{r^{2}},\qquad r\in[5,15],blackboard_P ( italic_h < divide start_ARG 100 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG roman_min ( 50 , divide start_ARG 50 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 50 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG = divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG , italic_r ∈ [ 5 , 15 ] ,

since 50⁢g/r2⩽50⁢g/25=19.6250𝑔superscript𝑟250𝑔2519.6250g/r^{2}\leqslant 50g/25=19.6250 italic_g / italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⩽ 50 italic_g / 25 = 19.62. Consequently,

ℙ⁡(R)=110⁢∫515gr2⁢dr=g10⁢(15−115)=g75=0.1308.ℙ𝑅110superscriptsubscript515𝑔superscript𝑟2differential-d𝑟𝑔1015115𝑔750.1308\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(R)=\frac{1}{10}\int_{5}^{15}\frac{g}{r^{2}}\,\mathrm% {d}r=\frac{g}{10}\left(\frac{1}{5}-\frac{1}{15}\right)=\frac{g}{75}=0.1308.blackboard_P ( italic_R ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 10 end_ARG ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 15 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG roman_d italic_r = divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 10 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 5 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 15 end_ARG ) = divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 75 end_ARG = 0.1308 .

Similarly, using the law of total expectation (see (A.4)) and the independence of hℎhitalic_h and v𝑣vitalic_v, we have that

ℙ⁡(S)ℙ𝑆\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(S)blackboard_P ( italic_S ) =ℙ⁡(g2⁢v2⋅10.52<h−2)=ℙ⁡(h>2+g2⁢v2⋅10.52)absentℙ⋅𝑔2superscript𝑣2superscript10.52ℎ2ℙℎ2⋅𝑔2superscript𝑣2superscript10.52\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\frac{g}{2v^{2}}\cdot 10.5^{2}<h-% 2\right)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(h>2+\frac{g}{2v^{2}}\cdot 10.5^{2}\right)= blackboard_P ( divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ⋅ 10.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < italic_h - 2 ) = blackboard_P ( italic_h > 2 + divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_v start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ⋅ 10.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT )
=110⁢∫515ℙ⁡(h>2+g2⁢r2⋅10.52)⁢drabsent110superscriptsubscript515ℙℎ2⋅𝑔2superscript𝑟2superscript10.52differential-d𝑟\displaystyle=\frac{1}{10}\int_{5}^{15}\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(h>2+% \frac{g}{2r^{2}}\cdot 10.5^{2}\right)\,\mathrm{d}r= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 10 end_ARG ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 15 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P ( italic_h > 2 + divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ⋅ 10.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_r
=110⁢∫515150⁢max⁡(50−(2+g2⁢r2⋅10.52),0)⁢dr,absent110superscriptsubscript515150502⋅𝑔2superscript𝑟2superscript10.520differential-d𝑟\displaystyle=\frac{1}{10}\int_{5}^{15}\frac{1}{50}\max\Big{(}50-\Big{(}2+% \frac{g}{2r^{2}}\cdot 10.5^{2}\Big{)},0\Big{)}\,\mathrm{d}r,= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 10 end_ARG ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 15 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG roman_max ( 50 - ( 2 + divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ⋅ 10.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) , 0 ) roman_d italic_r ,

where 50−(2+g2⁢r2⋅10.52)⩾0502⋅𝑔2superscript𝑟2superscript10.52050-\Big{(}2+\frac{g}{2r^{2}}\cdot 10.5^{2}\Big{)}\geqslant 050 - ( 2 + divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ⋅ 10.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ⩾ 0 for all r∈[5,15]𝑟515r\in[5,15]italic_r ∈ [ 5 , 15 ], since it holds if and only if r2⩾10.52⁢g/96≈11.27superscript𝑟2superscript10.52𝑔9611.27r^{2}\geqslant 10.5^{2}g/96\approx 11.27italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⩾ 10.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_g / 96 ≈ 11.27, which is true since r⩾5𝑟5r\geqslant 5italic_r ⩾ 5. Hence we get that

ℙ⁡(S)ℙ𝑆\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(S)blackboard_P ( italic_S ) =1500⁢∫515(48−g2⁢r2⋅10.52)⁢drabsent1500superscriptsubscript51548⋅𝑔2superscript𝑟2superscript10.52differential-d𝑟\displaystyle=\frac{1}{500}\int_{5}^{15}\Big{(}48-\frac{g}{2r^{2}}\cdot 10.5^{% 2}\Big{)}\,\mathrm{d}r= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 500 end_ARG ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 5 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 15 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 48 - divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_r start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ⋅ 10.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_r
=1500⁢(48⁢(15−5)+10.52⁢g2⁢(115−15))=4850−110.25⁢g7500≈0.8158.absent150048155superscript10.52𝑔2115154850110.25𝑔75000.8158\displaystyle=\frac{1}{500}\Big{(}48(15-5)+\frac{10.5^{2}g}{2}\Big{(}\frac{1}{% 15}-\frac{1}{5}\Big{)}\Big{)}=\frac{48}{50}-\frac{110.25g}{7500}\approx 0.8158.= divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 500 end_ARG ( 48 ( 15 - 5 ) + divide start_ARG 10.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 15 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 5 end_ARG ) ) = divide start_ARG 48 end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 110.25 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 7500 end_ARG ≈ 0.8158 .

Note that we calculated the same value for ℙ⁡(S)ℙ𝑆\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(S)blackboard_P ( italic_S ) using Methods 1 and 2, as it was expected.

Using the values of ℙ⁡(R)ℙ𝑅\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(R)blackboard_P ( italic_R ) and ℙ⁡(S)ℙ𝑆\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(S)blackboard_P ( italic_S ), (2.1) implies that

1−ℙ⁡(R)−ℙ⁡(S)=1−g75−4850+110.25⁢g7500=250+(110.257500−175)⁢g≈0.05341.1ℙ𝑅ℙ𝑆1𝑔754850110.25𝑔7500250110.257500175𝑔0.05341\displaystyle 1-\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(R)-\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(S)=1-% \frac{g}{75}-\frac{48}{50}+\frac{110.25g}{7500}=\frac{2}{50}+\left(\frac{110.2% 5}{7500}-\frac{1}{75}\right)g\approx 0.05341.1 - blackboard_P ( italic_R ) - blackboard_P ( italic_S ) = 1 - divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 75 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 48 end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG + divide start_ARG 110.25 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 7500 end_ARG = divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG + ( divide start_ARG 110.25 end_ARG start_ARG 7500 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 75 end_ARG ) italic_g ≈ 0.05341 .

(iii). We have to calculate the conditional probability ℙ⁡(h⁢<10|⁢d<10)ℙℎbra10𝑑10\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(h<10\,|\,d<10)blackboard_P ( italic_h < 10 | italic_d < 10 ). By part (ii), we have that ℙ⁡(d<10)=975ℙ𝑑10975\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(d<10)=\frac{9}{75}blackboard_P ( italic_d < 10 ) = divide start_ARG 9 end_ARG start_ARG 75 end_ARG, and hence, by the definition of conditional probability,

ℙ⁡(h⁢<10|⁢d<10)=ℙ⁡(h<10,d<10)ℙ⁡(d<10)=75g⁢ℙ⁡(h<10,d<10).ℙℎbra10𝑑10ℙℎ10𝑑10ℙ𝑑1075𝑔ℙℎ10𝑑10\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(h<10\,|\,d<10)=\frac{\operatorname{% \mathbb{P}}(h<10,d<10)}{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(d<10)}=\frac{75}{g}% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(h<10,d<10).blackboard_P ( italic_h < 10 | italic_d < 10 ) = divide start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_h < 10 , italic_d < 10 ) end_ARG start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_d < 10 ) end_ARG = divide start_ARG 75 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_h < 10 , italic_d < 10 ) .

Using Figure 5

and the method of geometric probabilities, we get that

ℙ⁡(h<10,d<10)ℙℎ10𝑑10\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(h<10,d<10)blackboard_P ( italic_h < 10 , italic_d < 10 ) =ℙ⁡(h<10,2⁢hg⋅v<10)=ℙ⁡(h<10,v<10⁢g2⋅1h)absentℙℎ10⋅2ℎ𝑔𝑣10ℙℎ10𝑣⋅10𝑔21ℎ\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(h<10,\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}\cdot v<1% 0\right)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(h<10,v<\frac{10\sqrt{g}}{\sqrt{2}}% \cdot\frac{1}{\sqrt{h}}\right)= blackboard_P ( italic_h < 10 , square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ italic_v < 10 ) = blackboard_P ( italic_h < 10 , italic_v < divide start_ARG 10 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_h end_ARG end_ARG )
=T50⁢(15−5)=T500,absent𝑇50155𝑇500\displaystyle=\frac{T}{50(15-5)}=\frac{T}{500},= divide start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 50 ( 15 - 5 ) end_ARG = divide start_ARG italic_T end_ARG start_ARG 500 end_ARG ,

where 500500500500 is the area of the rectangle [0,50]×[5,15]050515[0,50]\times[5,15][ 0 , 50 ] × [ 5 , 15 ] (”total” area), and the ”probable” area T𝑇Titalic_T can be calculated as follows. Using (2.2) and (2.3), we have that

T𝑇\displaystyle Titalic_T =∫0g2⋅1.52(15−5)⁢dp+∫g2⋅1.5210(10⁢g2⋅1p−5)⁢dpabsentsuperscriptsubscript0𝑔⋅2superscript1.52155differential-d𝑝superscriptsubscript𝑔⋅2superscript1.5210⋅10𝑔21𝑝5differential-d𝑝\displaystyle=\int_{0}^{\frac{g}{2\cdot 1.5^{2}}}(15-5)\,\mathrm{d}p+\int_{% \frac{g}{2\cdot 1.5^{2}}}^{10}\left(\frac{10\sqrt{g}}{\sqrt{2}}\cdot\frac{1}{% \sqrt{p}}-5\right)\,\mathrm{d}p= ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 ⋅ 1.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 15 - 5 ) roman_d italic_p + ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 ⋅ 1.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 10 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG 10 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_p end_ARG end_ARG - 5 ) roman_d italic_p
=10⁢g2⋅1.52+10⁢2⁢g⁢(10−g1.5⁢2)−5⁢(10−g2⋅1.52)absent10𝑔⋅2superscript1.52102𝑔10𝑔1.52510𝑔⋅2superscript1.52\displaystyle=\frac{10g}{2\cdot 1.5^{2}}+10\sqrt{2g}\left(\sqrt{10}-\frac{% \sqrt{g}}{1.5\sqrt{2}}\right)-5\left(10-\frac{g}{2\cdot 1.5^{2}}\right)= divide start_ARG 10 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 ⋅ 1.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + 10 square-root start_ARG 2 italic_g end_ARG ( square-root start_ARG 10 end_ARG - divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 1.5 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG ) - 5 ( 10 - divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 ⋅ 1.5 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG )
=10⁢g4.5+10⁢20⁢g−10⁢g1.5−50+5⁢g4.5absent10𝑔4.51020𝑔10𝑔1.5505𝑔4.5\displaystyle=\frac{10g}{4.5}+10\sqrt{20g}-\frac{10g}{1.5}-50+\frac{5g}{4.5}= divide start_ARG 10 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 4.5 end_ARG + 10 square-root start_ARG 20 italic_g end_ARG - divide start_ARG 10 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 1.5 end_ARG - 50 + divide start_ARG 5 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 4.5 end_ARG
=−15⁢g4.5+10⁢20⁢g−50.absent15𝑔4.51020𝑔50\displaystyle=-\frac{15g}{4.5}+10\sqrt{20g}-50.= - divide start_ARG 15 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 4.5 end_ARG + 10 square-root start_ARG 20 italic_g end_ARG - 50 .

We remark that the probability ℙ⁡(h<10,d<10)ℙℎ10𝑑10\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(h<10,d<10)blackboard_P ( italic_h < 10 , italic_d < 10 ) could be determined using the law of total expectation as well similarly as in the solution of part (ii) (by Method 2), but we will leave it for now.

All in all, we get that

ℙ⁡(h⁢<10|⁢d<10)=75500⁢(−154.5+10⁢20g−50g)≈0.8772.ℙℎbra10𝑑1075500154.51020𝑔50𝑔0.8772\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(h<10\,|\,d<10)=\frac{75}{500}\left(-% \frac{15}{4.5}+\frac{10\sqrt{20}}{\sqrt{g}}-\frac{50}{g}\right)\approx 0.8772.blackboard_P ( italic_h < 10 | italic_d < 10 ) = divide start_ARG 75 end_ARG start_ARG 500 end_ARG ( - divide start_ARG 15 end_ARG start_ARG 4.5 end_ARG + divide start_ARG 10 square-root start_ARG 20 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG - divide start_ARG 50 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ) ≈ 0.8772 .

□□\Box□

We note that students may formulate and solve a natural counterpart of Exercise 2.1 by choosing the height (where Thomas stops) according to a (discrete) uniform distribution, for example, on the finite set {1⁢m,2⁢m,…,49⁢m,50⁢m}1m2m…49m50m\{1\,\mathrm{m},2\,\mathrm{m},\ldots,49\,\mathrm{m},50\,\mathrm{m}\}{ 1 roman_m , 2 roman_m , … , 49 roman_m , 50 roman_m }. Of course, one could also consider other discrete or absolutely continuous distributions with range in [0,50]050[0,50][ 0 , 50 ]. For example, the discrete distribution on the set {10⁢m,20⁢m,30⁢m,40⁢m,50⁢m}10m20m30m40m50m\{10\,\mathrm{m},20\,\mathrm{m},30\,\mathrm{m},40\,\mathrm{m},50\,\mathrm{m}\}{ 10 roman_m , 20 roman_m , 30 roman_m , 40 roman_m , 50 roman_m } with corresponding probabilities 40100,30100,20100,9100,110040100301002010091001100\frac{40}{100},\frac{30}{100},\frac{20}{100},\frac{9}{100},\frac{1}{100}divide start_ARG 40 end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG , divide start_ARG 30 end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG , divide start_ARG 20 end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG , divide start_ARG 9 end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG would may suggest that Thomas has a fear of heights.

2.2 Exercise.

Let us consider a rectangular cuboid-shape building with a height of 50 meters, standing on horizontal ground. From the bottom of the building, Anne takes the elevator up. Anne stops at a height hℎhitalic_h chosen according to a uniform distribution on the interval [0⁢m,50⁢m]0m50m[0\,\mathrm{m},50\,\mathrm{m}][ 0 roman_m , 50 roman_m ], and from the edge of the building she throws a ball with velocity v𝑣vitalic_v of which the magnitude is 151515\,15msms\mathrm{\frac{m}{s}}divide start_ARG roman_m end_ARG start_ARG roman_s end_ARG and its direction is perpendicular to the wall of the building. Parallel to Anne’s building, there is another rectangular cuboid-shape building, 15 metres away, its height is 50505050 meters. If the thrown ball reaches the opposite house, then it bounces back elastically from its wall, and if the rebounced ball also reaches the wall of Anne’s house, then it rebounces (elastically) from it as well, and so on.

  • (i)

    What is the distribution of the number of times the ball rebounces before it hits the ground?

  • (ii)

    What is the expectation, variance and relative standard deviation of the number of times the ball rebounces before it hits the ground?

  • (iii)

    What is the probability that the ball hits the ground closer to Anne’s building?

Solution. (i). It is known that if we launch a ball horizontally at height hℎhitalic_h with velocity v𝑣vitalic_v, then the total (horizontal) distance of the whole journey before the ball hits the ground is d:=2⁢hg⋅vassign𝑑⋅2ℎ𝑔𝑣d:=\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}\cdot vitalic_d := square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ italic_v.

Since we assumed that the rebounds (collisions) are elastic, the trajectory after the first collision (provided that such a collision occurs) is the reflection of the imaginary continuation of the trajectory before the first collision after the colliding surface (wall) on the colliding surface. Similarly, the trajectory after the second collision (provided that such a collision occurs) is the reflection of the imaginary continuation of the trajectory after the first collision after the second colliding surface on the (second) colliding surface. This train of thought can be continued in a similar way for all of the collisions that occur. Consequently, it is enough to consider a single projectile motion, launched at height hℎhitalic_h with horizontal velocity v𝑣vitalic_v.

Let the random variable ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ denote the number of times the ball rebounces before it hits the ground.

For all nonnegative integer k𝑘kitalic_k, we have that

{ξ=k}={ the distance d traveled horizontally by the ball before it hits the ground\displaystyle\{\xi=k\}=\Big{\{}\text{ the distance $d$ traveled horizontally % by the ball before it hits the ground}{ italic_ξ = italic_k } = { the distance italic_d traveled horizontally by the ball before it hits the ground
 is in [15⁢k,15⁢(k+1)) }.\displaystyle\phantom{\{\xi=k\}=\Big{\{}\,}\text{ is in $[15k,15(k+1))$ }\Big{% \}}.is in [ 15 italic_k , 15 ( italic_k + 1 ) ) } .

Since the maximum value of d𝑑ditalic_d is 2⋅50g⋅15≈47.89⋅⋅250𝑔1547.89\sqrt{\frac{2\cdot 50}{g}}\cdot 15\approx 47.89square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 ⋅ 50 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ 15 ≈ 47.89, the ball can rebound maximum three times. Hence the range of ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ is {0,1,2,3}0123\{0,1,2,3\}{ 0 , 1 , 2 , 3 }, and, using that hℎhitalic_h is a uniformly distributed random variable on the interval [0,50]050[0,50][ 0 , 50 ], we get that

ℙ⁡(ξ=0)=ℙ⁡(d<15)=ℙ⁡(2⁢hg⋅15<15)=ℙ⁡(h<g/2)=g/250=g100,ℙ𝜉0ℙ𝑑15ℙ⋅2ℎ𝑔1515ℙℎ𝑔2𝑔250𝑔100\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=0)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(d<15)=% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}\cdot 15<15\right)=% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(h<g/2)=\frac{g/2}{50}=\frac{g}{100},blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = 0 ) = blackboard_P ( italic_d < 15 ) = blackboard_P ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ 15 < 15 ) = blackboard_P ( italic_h < italic_g / 2 ) = divide start_ARG italic_g / 2 end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG = divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG ,
ℙ⁡(ξ=1)=ℙ⁡(15⩽d<30)=ℙ⁡(15⩽2⁢hg⋅15<30)=ℙ⁡(g2⩽h<4⁢g2)=3⁢g100,ℙ𝜉1ℙ15𝑑30ℙ15⋅2ℎ𝑔1530ℙ𝑔2ℎ4𝑔23𝑔100\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=1)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(15% \leqslant d<30)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(15\leqslant\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}% \cdot 15<30\right)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\frac{g}{2}\leqslant h<\frac% {4g}{2}\right)=\frac{3g}{100},blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = 1 ) = blackboard_P ( 15 ⩽ italic_d < 30 ) = blackboard_P ( 15 ⩽ square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ 15 < 30 ) = blackboard_P ( divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ⩽ italic_h < divide start_ARG 4 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) = divide start_ARG 3 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG ,
ℙ⁡(ξ=2)=ℙ⁡(30⩽d<45)=ℙ⁡(30⩽2⁢hg⋅15<45)=ℙ⁡(4⁢g2⩽h<9⁢g2)=5⁢g100,ℙ𝜉2ℙ30𝑑45ℙ30⋅2ℎ𝑔1545ℙ4𝑔2ℎ9𝑔25𝑔100\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=2)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(30% \leqslant d<45)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(30\leqslant\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}% \cdot 15<45\right)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\frac{4g}{2}\leqslant h<% \frac{9g}{2}\right)=\frac{5g}{100},blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = 2 ) = blackboard_P ( 30 ⩽ italic_d < 45 ) = blackboard_P ( 30 ⩽ square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ 15 < 45 ) = blackboard_P ( divide start_ARG 4 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ⩽ italic_h < divide start_ARG 9 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) = divide start_ARG 5 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG ,
ℙ⁡(ξ=3)=ℙ⁡(45⩽d<65)=1−ℙ⁡(d<45)=1−(ℙ⁡(ξ=0)+ℙ⁡(ξ=1)+ℙ⁡(ξ=2))ℙ𝜉3ℙ45𝑑651ℙ𝑑451ℙ𝜉0ℙ𝜉1ℙ𝜉2\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=3)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(45% \leqslant d<65)=1-\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(d<45)=1-(\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}% (\xi=0)+\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=1)+\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=2))blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = 3 ) = blackboard_P ( 45 ⩽ italic_d < 65 ) = 1 - blackboard_P ( italic_d < 45 ) = 1 - ( blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = 0 ) + blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = 1 ) + blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = 2 ) )
=1−9⁢g100.absent19𝑔100\displaystyle\phantom{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=3)}=1-\frac{9g}{100}.= 1 - divide start_ARG 9 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG .

(ii). The expected value of ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ takes the form

𝔼⁡(ξ)𝔼𝜉\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi)blackboard_E ( italic_ξ ) =∑k=03k⁢ℙ⁡(ξ=k)=1⋅3⁢g100+2⋅5⁢g100+3⋅100−9⁢g100=3⁢g+10⁢g+300−27⁢g100absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑘03𝑘ℙ𝜉𝑘⋅13𝑔100⋅25𝑔100⋅31009𝑔1003𝑔10𝑔30027𝑔100\displaystyle=\sum_{k=0}^{3}k\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=k)=1\cdot\frac{3g}{% 100}+2\cdot\frac{5g}{100}+3\cdot\frac{100-9g}{100}=\frac{3g+10g+300-27g}{100}= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = italic_k ) = 1 ⋅ divide start_ARG 3 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG + 2 ⋅ divide start_ARG 5 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG + 3 ⋅ divide start_ARG 100 - 9 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG = divide start_ARG 3 italic_g + 10 italic_g + 300 - 27 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG
=300−14⁢g100≈1.627.absent30014𝑔1001.627\displaystyle=\frac{300-14g}{100}\approx 1.627.= divide start_ARG 300 - 14 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG ≈ 1.627 .

Now, we turn to calculate the variance and standard deviation of ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ. We have that

𝔼⁡(ξ2)𝔼superscript𝜉2\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi^{2})blackboard_E ( italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) =∑k=03k2⁢ℙ⁡(ξ=k)=1⋅3⁢g100+4⋅5⁢g100+9⋅100−9⁢g100=3⁢g+20⁢g+900−81⁢g100absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑘03superscript𝑘2ℙ𝜉𝑘⋅13𝑔100⋅45𝑔100⋅91009𝑔1003𝑔20𝑔90081𝑔100\displaystyle=\sum_{k=0}^{3}k^{2}\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=k)=1\cdot\frac{% 3g}{100}+4\cdot\frac{5g}{100}+9\cdot\frac{100-9g}{100}=\frac{3g+20g+900-81g}{1% 00}= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = italic_k ) = 1 ⋅ divide start_ARG 3 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG + 4 ⋅ divide start_ARG 5 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG + 9 ⋅ divide start_ARG 100 - 9 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG = divide start_ARG 3 italic_g + 20 italic_g + 900 - 81 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG
=900−58⁢g100≈3.3102.absent90058𝑔1003.3102\displaystyle=\frac{900-58g}{100}\approx 3.3102.= divide start_ARG 900 - 58 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG ≈ 3.3102 .

Consequently, the variance of ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ takes the form

𝔻2⁡(ξ)=𝔼⁡(ξ2)−(𝔼⁡(ξ))2=900−58⁢g100−(300−14⁢g100)2=2600⁢g−196⁢g10000≈0.6644,superscript𝔻2𝜉𝔼superscript𝜉2superscript𝔼𝜉290058𝑔100superscript30014𝑔10022600𝑔196𝑔100000.6644\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{D}}^{2}(\xi)=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi^% {2})-(\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi))^{2}=\frac{900-58g}{100}-\left(\frac{300-% 14g}{100}\right)^{2}=\frac{2600g-196g}{10000}\approx 0.6644,blackboard_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ξ ) = blackboard_E ( italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - ( blackboard_E ( italic_ξ ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 900 - 58 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG - ( divide start_ARG 300 - 14 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 2600 italic_g - 196 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 10000 end_ARG ≈ 0.6644 ,

and hence the standard deviation of ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ is

𝔻⁡(ξ)=2600⁢g−196⁢g210000=650⁢g−49⁢g250≈0.8151.𝔻𝜉2600𝑔196superscript𝑔210000650𝑔49superscript𝑔2500.8151\operatorname{\mathbb{D}}(\xi)=\sqrt{\frac{2600g-196g^{2}}{10000}}=\frac{\sqrt% {650g-49g^{2}}}{50}\approx 0.8151.blackboard_D ( italic_ξ ) = square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2600 italic_g - 196 italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 10000 end_ARG end_ARG = divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 650 italic_g - 49 italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG ≈ 0.8151 .

This implies that the relative standard deviation of ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ is

RSD⁡(ξ)=650⁢g−49⁢g250300−14⁢g100=650⁢g−49⁢g2150−7⁢g≈0.5011.RSD𝜉650𝑔49superscript𝑔25030014𝑔100650𝑔49superscript𝑔21507𝑔0.5011\operatorname{RSD}(\xi)=\frac{\frac{\sqrt{650g-49g^{2}}}{50}}{\frac{300-14g}{1% 00}}=\frac{\sqrt{650g-49g^{2}}}{150-7g}\approx 0.5011.roman_RSD ( italic_ξ ) = divide start_ARG divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 650 italic_g - 49 italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG 300 - 14 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 100 end_ARG end_ARG = divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 650 italic_g - 49 italic_g start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 150 - 7 italic_g end_ARG ≈ 0.5011 .

(iii). Let A𝐴Aitalic_A be the event that the ball hits the ground closer to Anne’s building. Using the additivity of probability and that the maximum value of d𝑑ditalic_d is 2⋅50g⋅15≈47.89⋅⋅250𝑔1547.89\sqrt{\frac{2\cdot 50}{g}}\cdot 15\approx 47.89square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 ⋅ 50 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ 15 ≈ 47.89 (see part (i)), we get that

ℙ⁡(A)ℙ𝐴\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A)blackboard_P ( italic_A ) =∑k=03ℙ⁡(A,ξ=k)absentsuperscriptsubscript𝑘03ℙ𝐴𝜉𝑘\displaystyle=\sum_{k=0}^{3}\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A,\xi=k)= ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P ( italic_A , italic_ξ = italic_k )
=ℙ⁡(d<7.5)+ℙ⁡(15+7.5⩽d<15+15)+ℙ⁡(30⩽d⩽30+7.5)absentℙ𝑑7.5ℙ157.5𝑑1515ℙ30𝑑307.5\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(d<7.5)+\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(15+7.% 5\leqslant d<15+15)+\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(30\leqslant d\leqslant 30+7.5)= blackboard_P ( italic_d < 7.5 ) + blackboard_P ( 15 + 7.5 ⩽ italic_d < 15 + 15 ) + blackboard_P ( 30 ⩽ italic_d ⩽ 30 + 7.5 )
+ℙ⁡(45+7.5⩽d<45+15)ℙ457.5𝑑4515\displaystyle\phantom{=\;}+\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(45+7.5\leqslant d<45+15)+ blackboard_P ( 45 + 7.5 ⩽ italic_d < 45 + 15 )
=ℙ⁡(d<7.5)+ℙ⁡(22.5⩽d<37.5)+0absentℙ𝑑7.5ℙ22.5𝑑37.50\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(d<7.5)+\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(22.5% \leqslant d<37.5)+0= blackboard_P ( italic_d < 7.5 ) + blackboard_P ( 22.5 ⩽ italic_d < 37.5 ) + 0
=ℙ⁡(2⁢hg⋅15<7.5)+ℙ⁡(22.5⩽2⁢hg⋅15<37.5)absentℙ⋅2ℎ𝑔157.5ℙ22.5⋅2ℎ𝑔1537.5\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}\cdot 15<7.5% \right)+\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(22.5\leqslant\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}\cdot 1% 5<37.5\right)= blackboard_P ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ 15 < 7.5 ) + blackboard_P ( 22.5 ⩽ square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ 15 < 37.5 )
=ℙ⁡(h⩽g8)+ℙ⁡(9⁢g8⩽h<25⁢g8)=150⁢(g8+(25−9)⁢g8)=17⁢g400≈0.4169.absentℙℎ𝑔8ℙ9𝑔8ℎ25𝑔8150𝑔8259𝑔817𝑔4000.4169\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(h\leqslant\frac{g}{8}\right)+% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\frac{9g}{8}\leqslant h<\frac{25g}{8}\right)=% \frac{1}{50}\left(\frac{g}{8}+\frac{(25-9)g}{8}\right)=\frac{17g}{400}\approx 0% .4169.= blackboard_P ( italic_h ⩽ divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG ) + blackboard_P ( divide start_ARG 9 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG ⩽ italic_h < divide start_ARG 25 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 50 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG + divide start_ARG ( 25 - 9 ) italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG ) = divide start_ARG 17 italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 400 end_ARG ≈ 0.4169 .

□□\Box□

Part (i) of the next Exercise 2.3 is a randomized version of Exercise 2 for 4-th grade high school students at the Ágoston Budó Physics Competition (1980) (see [6]) in the sense that we randomly choose the height from which we drop the ball. Parts (ii), (iii) and (iv) of Exercise 2.3 contain new probabilistic-type questions to the same phenomena.

2.3 Exercise.

From a height chosen uniformly distributed between 00 and 1111 meters, we drop a ball on the table. We assume that the ball loses 5%percent55\%5 % of its velocity by each collision with the table.

  • (i)

    What is the density function, expectation, variance and relative standard deviation of the total time (in seconds) that elapses before the ball stops moving?

  • (ii)

    What is the density function, expectation, variance and relative standard deviation of the total distance (in meters) that the ball travels during its motion?

  • (iii)

    What is the probability that the ball ends its movement earlier than an identical ball dropped on the table from a height of 0.50.50.50.5 meters? Calculate the same probability if 0.50.50.50.5 meters is replaced by 4949\frac{4}{9}divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG meters! What could be the reason for choosing 4949\frac{4}{9}divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG meters in the previous task?

  • (iv)

    Let ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ denote a random variable that counts the number of times the ball is at a height of 0.10.10.10.1 meter during its movement. Let us determine the distribution and expectation of ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ!

Solution. Let h0subscriptℎ0h_{0}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denote the number of metres from which the ball is dropped. Then h0subscriptℎ0h_{0}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is uniformly distributed on the interval [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ]. Let us introduce the following notations: for each nonnegative integer n𝑛nitalic_n, let vn+1:=0.95⁢vnassignsubscript𝑣𝑛10.95subscript𝑣𝑛v_{n+1}:=0.95\,v_{n}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := 0.95 italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where v0subscript𝑣0v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the velocity of a ball dropped from a height of h0subscriptℎ0h_{0}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT when it hits the ground. The movement that takes place (bouncing) is an infinite sequence of consecutive free falls and vertical upward projectile motions. A ball dropped from a height of h0subscriptℎ0h_{0}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT takes time t0:=2⁢h0gassignsubscript𝑡02subscriptℎ0𝑔t_{0}:=\sqrt{\frac{2h_{0}}{g}}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG to hit the ground, and then its velocity is v0=g⁢t0=2⁢g⁢h0subscript𝑣0𝑔subscript𝑡02𝑔subscriptℎ0v_{0}=gt_{0}=\sqrt{2gh_{0}}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_g italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = square-root start_ARG 2 italic_g italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG.

By the assumption, the initial velocity of the vertical upward projectile motion after the first bounce is v1=0.95⁢v0subscript𝑣10.95subscript𝑣0v_{1}=0.95\,v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.95 italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. It is known that the time to reach the maximum height is t1:=v1gassignsubscript𝑡1subscript𝑣1𝑔t_{1}:=\frac{v_{1}}{g}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG and the maximum height of the projectile motion in question is v122⁢gsuperscriptsubscript𝑣122𝑔\frac{v_{1}^{2}}{2g}divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_g end_ARG. The new (second) fall time is t1′:=t1assignsuperscriptsubscript𝑡1′subscript𝑡1t_{1}^{\prime}:=t_{1}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, since there is no energy loss, and the velocity at the (second) landing is 2⁢g⁢v122⁢g=v12𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑣122𝑔subscript𝑣1\sqrt{2g\frac{v_{1}^{2}}{2g}}=v_{1}square-root start_ARG 2 italic_g divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_g end_ARG end_ARG = italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (that is, it is equal to the initial velocity of the vertical upward projectile motion after the first rebounce).

Similarly, for the vertical upward projectile motion after the second rebounce, by the assumption, we have that its initial velocity is v2=0.95⁢v1=0.952⁢v0subscript𝑣20.95subscript𝑣1superscript0.952subscript𝑣0v_{2}=0.95v_{1}=0.95^{2}v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.95 italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the time to reach its maximum height is t1:=v1gassignsubscript𝑡1subscript𝑣1𝑔t_{1}:=\frac{v_{1}}{g}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG, its maximum height is v222⁢gsuperscriptsubscript𝑣222𝑔\frac{v_{2}^{2}}{2g}divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_g end_ARG, and its fall time is t2′:=t2assignsuperscriptsubscript𝑡2′subscript𝑡2t_{2}^{\prime}:=t_{2}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, since there is no energy loss.

By induction, for the vertical upward projectile motion after the nthsuperscript𝑛thn^{\mathrm{th}}italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_th end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT rebounce, by the assumption, we have that its initial velocity is vn=0.95n⁢v0subscript𝑣𝑛superscript0.95𝑛subscript𝑣0v_{n}=0.95^{n}v_{0}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, the time to reach its maximum height is tn:=vng=0.95n⁢v0gassignsubscript𝑡𝑛subscript𝑣𝑛𝑔superscript0.95𝑛subscript𝑣0𝑔t_{n}:=\frac{v_{n}}{g}=\frac{0.95^{n}v_{0}}{g}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG = divide start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG, its maximum height is vn22⁢gsuperscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛22𝑔\frac{v_{n}^{2}}{2g}divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_g end_ARG, and its fall time is tn′:=tnassignsuperscriptsubscript𝑡𝑛′subscript𝑡𝑛t_{n}^{\prime}:=t_{n}italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT := italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, since there is no energy loss.

Consequently, the total time that elapses before the ball stops moving is

t:=t0+t1+t1′+t2+t2′+⋯=t0+∑n=1∞(tn+tn′)=t0+2⁢∑n=1∞tn,assign𝑡subscript𝑡0subscript𝑡1superscriptsubscript𝑡1′subscript𝑡2superscriptsubscript𝑡2′⋯subscript𝑡0superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑡𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑡𝑛′subscript𝑡02superscriptsubscript𝑛1subscript𝑡𝑛\displaystyle t:=t_{0}+t_{1}+t_{1}^{\prime}+t_{2}+t_{2}^{\prime}+\cdots=t_{0}+% \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(t_{n}+t_{n}^{\prime})=t_{0}+2\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}t_{n},italic_t := italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + ⋯ = italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ,

and the total distance that the ball travels during its motion is

s:=h0+2⁢v122⁢g+2⁢v222⁢g+⋯=h0+1g⁢∑n=1∞vn2.assign𝑠subscriptℎ02superscriptsubscript𝑣122𝑔2superscriptsubscript𝑣222𝑔⋯subscriptℎ01𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑛1superscriptsubscript𝑣𝑛2s:=h_{0}+2\frac{v_{1}^{2}}{2g}+2\frac{v_{2}^{2}}{2g}+\cdots=h_{0}+\frac{1}{g}% \sum_{n=1}^{\infty}v_{n}^{2}.italic_s := italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_g end_ARG + 2 divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_g end_ARG + ⋯ = italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Using these two formulas, we get that

t𝑡\displaystyle titalic_t =2⁢h0g+2⁢∑n=1∞0.95n⁢v0g=2⁢h0g+2g⁢2⁢g⁢h0⁢∑n=1∞0.95n=2⁢h0g+2⁢2⁢h0g⁢0.951−0.95absent2subscriptℎ0𝑔2superscriptsubscript𝑛1superscript0.95𝑛subscript𝑣0𝑔2subscriptℎ0𝑔2𝑔2𝑔subscriptℎ0superscriptsubscript𝑛1superscript0.95𝑛2subscriptℎ0𝑔22subscriptℎ0𝑔0.9510.95\displaystyle=\sqrt{\frac{2h_{0}}{g}}+2\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}\frac{0.95^{n}v_{0}}% {g}=\sqrt{\frac{2h_{0}}{g}}+\frac{2}{g}\sqrt{2gh_{0}}\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}0.95^{% n}=\sqrt{\frac{2h_{0}}{g}}+2\sqrt{\frac{2h_{0}}{g}}\frac{0.95}{1-0.95}= square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG + 2 ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG = square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG + divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 italic_g italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG + 2 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG divide start_ARG 0.95 end_ARG start_ARG 1 - 0.95 end_ARG

and

s=h0+1g⁢∑n=1∞(0.95n⁢v0)2=h0+v02g⁢∑n=1∞0.952⁢n=h0+2⁢h0⁢0.9521−0.952=76139⁢h0.𝑠subscriptℎ01𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑛1superscriptsuperscript0.95𝑛subscript𝑣02subscriptℎ0superscriptsubscript𝑣02𝑔superscriptsubscript𝑛1superscript0.952𝑛subscriptℎ02subscriptℎ0superscript0.9521superscript0.95276139subscriptℎ0\displaystyle s=h_{0}+\frac{1}{g}\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}(0.95^{n}v_{0})^{2}=h_{0}+% \frac{v_{0}^{2}}{g}\sum_{n=1}^{\infty}0.95^{2n}=h_{0}+2h_{0}\frac{0.95^{2}}{1-% 0.95^{2}}=\frac{761}{39}h_{0}.italic_s = italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + 2 italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 1 - 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG = divide start_ARG 761 end_ARG start_ARG 39 end_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT .

(i). First, we determine the cumulative distribution function of t𝑡titalic_t. If x⩽0𝑥0x\leqslant 0italic_x ⩽ 0, then ℙ⁡(t<x)=0ℙ𝑡𝑥0\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(t<x)=0blackboard_P ( italic_t < italic_x ) = 0; if x⩾39⁢2g𝑥392𝑔x\geqslant 39\sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}italic_x ⩾ 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG, then ℙ⁡(t<x)=1ℙ𝑡𝑥1\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(t<x)=1blackboard_P ( italic_t < italic_x ) = 1; and if x∈(0,39⁢2g)𝑥0392𝑔x\in\Big{(}0,39\sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}\Big{)}italic_x ∈ ( 0 , 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ), then we have that

ℙ⁡(t<x)=ℙ⁡(39⁢2g⁢h0<x)=ℙ⁡(h0<g3042⁢x2)=g3042⁢x2.ℙ𝑡𝑥ℙ392𝑔subscriptℎ0𝑥ℙsubscriptℎ0𝑔3042superscript𝑥2𝑔3042superscript𝑥2\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(t<x)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(39% \sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}\sqrt{h_{0}}<x\right)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(h_{0}<% \frac{g}{3042}x^{2}\right)=\frac{g}{3042}x^{2}.blackboard_P ( italic_t < italic_x ) = blackboard_P ( 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG < italic_x ) = blackboard_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 3042 end_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 3042 end_ARG italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Consequently, the cumulative distribution function Ft:ℝ→[0,1]:subscript𝐹𝑡→ℝ01F_{t}:\mathbb{R}\to[0,1]italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : blackboard_R → [ 0 , 1 ] of t𝑡titalic_t takes the form

This implies that the density function ft:ℝ→[0,∞):subscript𝑓𝑡→ℝ0f_{t}:\mathbb{R}\to[0,\infty)italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : blackboard_R → [ 0 , ∞ ) of t𝑡titalic_t takes the form

The expected value of the total time t𝑡titalic_t that elapses before the ball stops moving is

𝔼⁡(t)=39⁢2g⁢𝔼⁡(h0)=39⁢2g⁢∫01x⁢dx=39⁢2g⋅23≈11.74.𝔼𝑡392𝑔𝔼subscriptℎ0392𝑔superscriptsubscript01𝑥differential-d𝑥⋅392𝑔2311.74\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(t)=39\sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}\operatorname{% \mathbb{E}}(\sqrt{h_{0}})=39\sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}\int_{0}^{1}\sqrt{x}\,\mathrm{d}% x=39\sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}\cdot\frac{2}{3}\approx 11.74.blackboard_E ( italic_t ) = 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG blackboard_E ( square-root start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) = 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG italic_x end_ARG roman_d italic_x = 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ≈ 11.74 .

Alternatively, we can also calculate the expected value of t𝑡titalic_t using its density function ftsubscript𝑓𝑡f_{t}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as follows:

𝔼⁡(t)=∫039⁢2gx⋅g1521⁢x⁢dx=g1521⋅(39⁢2g)33=39⁢2g⋅23.𝔼𝑡superscriptsubscript0392𝑔⋅𝑥𝑔1521𝑥differential-d𝑥⋅𝑔1521superscript392𝑔33⋅392𝑔23\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(t)=\int_{0}^{39\sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}}x% \cdot\frac{g}{1521}x\,\mathrm{d}x=\frac{g}{1521}\cdot\frac{\left(39\sqrt{\frac% {2}{g}}\right)^{3}}{3}=39\sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}\cdot\frac{2}{3}.blackboard_E ( italic_t ) = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x ⋅ divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 1521 end_ARG italic_x roman_d italic_x = divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 1521 end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG ( 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG = 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG .

We call the attention to the fact that 𝔼⁡(t)𝔼𝑡\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(t)blackboard_E ( italic_t ) is not equal to the total time that elapses before a ball dropped from a height of 0.50.50.50.5 meters stops moving (39⁢2g⁢0.5≈12.45)392𝑔0.512.45\Big{(}39\sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}\sqrt{0.5}\approx 12.45\Big{)}( 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG square-root start_ARG 0.5 end_ARG ≈ 12.45 ), but it is equal to the total time that elapses before a ball dropped from a height of 4949\frac{4}{9}divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG stops moving.

Now, we turn to calculate the variance and standard deviation of t𝑡titalic_t. We have that

𝔼⁡(t2)=392⋅2g⁢𝔼⁡(h0)=392⋅2g⋅12=392g,𝔼superscript𝑡2⋅superscript3922𝑔𝔼subscriptℎ0⋅superscript3922𝑔12superscript392𝑔\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(t^{2})=39^{2}\cdot\frac{2}{g}% \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(h_{0})=39^{2}\cdot\frac{2}{g}\cdot\frac{1}{2}=\frac{% 39^{2}}{g},blackboard_E ( italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 39 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG blackboard_E ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 39 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG = divide start_ARG 39 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ,

and hence the variance and standard deviation of t𝑡titalic_t take the following forms

𝔻2⁡(t)=392g−392⋅2g⋅49=3929⁢g≈17.23,superscript𝔻2𝑡superscript392𝑔⋅superscript3922𝑔49superscript3929𝑔17.23\operatorname{\mathbb{D}}^{2}(t)=\frac{39^{2}}{g}-39^{2}\cdot\frac{2}{g}\cdot% \frac{4}{9}=\frac{39^{2}}{9g}\approx 17.23,blackboard_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_t ) = divide start_ARG 39 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG - 39 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG = divide start_ARG 39 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 9 italic_g end_ARG ≈ 17.23 ,

and

This implies that the relative standard deviation of t𝑡titalic_t is

(ii). Since s=76139⁢h0𝑠76139subscriptℎ0s=\frac{761}{39}h_{0}italic_s = divide start_ARG 761 end_ARG start_ARG 39 end_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and h0subscriptℎ0h_{0}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is uniformly distributed on the interval [0,1]01[0,1][ 0 , 1 ], we get that s𝑠sitalic_s is uniformly distributed on the interval [0,76139]076139\big{[}0,\frac{761}{39}\big{]}[ 0 , divide start_ARG 761 end_ARG start_ARG 39 end_ARG ], and its density function fs:ℝ→[0,∞):subscript𝑓𝑠→ℝ0f_{s}:\mathbb{R}\to[0,\infty)italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : blackboard_R → [ 0 , ∞ ) takes the form
