The expected value of the total distance s𝑠sitalic_s that the ball travels during its motion is

𝔼⁡(s)=76139⁢𝔼⁡(h0)=76139⋅12=76178≈9.756.𝔼𝑠76139𝔼subscriptℎ0⋅7613912761789.756\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(s)=\frac{761}{39}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(h_{0})=% \frac{761}{39}\cdot\frac{1}{2}=\frac{761}{78}\approx 9.756.blackboard_E ( italic_s ) = divide start_ARG 761 end_ARG start_ARG 39 end_ARG blackboard_E ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 761 end_ARG start_ARG 39 end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG = divide start_ARG 761 end_ARG start_ARG 78 end_ARG ≈ 9.756 .

Note that 𝔼⁡(s)𝔼𝑠\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(s)blackboard_E ( italic_s ) is equal to the total distance that a ball dropped from a height of 0.50.50.50.5 meters travels during its motion.

Now, we turn to calculate the variance and standard deviation of s𝑠sitalic_s. We have that

𝔼⁡(s2)=∫0761/39x2⋅39761⁢dx=39761⋅13⁢(76139)3=13⁢(76139)2,𝔼superscript𝑠2superscriptsubscript076139⋅superscript𝑥239761differential-d𝑥⋅3976113superscript76139313superscript761392\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(s^{2})=\int_{0}^{761/39}x^{2}\cdot\frac% {39}{761}\,\mathrm{d}x=\frac{39}{761}\cdot\frac{1}{3}\left(\frac{761}{39}% \right)^{3}=\frac{1}{3}\left(\frac{761}{39}\right)^{2},blackboard_E ( italic_s start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 761 / 39 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⋅ divide start_ARG 39 end_ARG start_ARG 761 end_ARG roman_d italic_x = divide start_ARG 39 end_ARG start_ARG 761 end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 761 end_ARG start_ARG 39 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 761 end_ARG start_ARG 39 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ,

and hence the variance and standard deviation of s𝑠sitalic_s take the following forms

𝔻2⁡(s)=13⁢(76139)2−(76178)2=112⁢(76139)2≈31.73,superscript𝔻2𝑠13superscript761392superscript761782112superscript76139231.73\operatorname{\mathbb{D}}^{2}(s)=\frac{1}{3}\left(\frac{761}{39}\right)^{2}-% \left(\frac{761}{78}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{12}\left(\frac{761}{39}\right)^{2}% \approx 31.73,blackboard_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_s ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 761 end_ARG start_ARG 39 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - ( divide start_ARG 761 end_ARG start_ARG 78 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 12 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 761 end_ARG start_ARG 39 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≈ 31.73 ,

and

𝔻⁡(s)=112⁢(76139)2=76178⁢3.𝔻𝑠112superscript761392761783\operatorname{\mathbb{D}}(s)=\sqrt{\frac{1}{12}\left(\frac{761}{39}\right)^{2}% }=\frac{761}{78\sqrt{3}}.blackboard_D ( italic_s ) = square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 12 end_ARG ( divide start_ARG 761 end_ARG start_ARG 39 end_ARG ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG = divide start_ARG 761 end_ARG start_ARG 78 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_ARG .

This implies that the relative standard deviation of s𝑠sitalic_s is

RSD⁡(s)=76178⁢376178=13≈0.5774.RSD𝑠76178376178130.5774\operatorname{RSD}(s)=\frac{\frac{761}{78\sqrt{3}}}{\frac{761}{78}}=\frac{1}{% \sqrt{3}}\approx 0.5774.roman_RSD ( italic_s ) = divide start_ARG divide start_ARG 761 end_ARG start_ARG 78 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG 761 end_ARG start_ARG 78 end_ARG end_ARG = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_ARG ≈ 0.5774 .

Since the relative standard deviation of s𝑠sitalic_s is greater than that of t𝑡titalic_t, roughly speaking, one can say that the level of dispersion of the values of s𝑠sitalic_s around it mean 𝔼⁡(s)𝔼𝑠\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(s)blackboard_E ( italic_s ) is greater than that of the values of t𝑡titalic_t around its mean 𝔼⁡(t)𝔼𝑡\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(t)blackboard_E ( italic_t ).

(iii). Then we have that

ℙ⁡(39⁢2g⁢h0<39⁢2g⁢0.5)=ℙ⁡(h0<0.5)=ℙ⁡(h0<0.5)=12,ℙ392𝑔subscriptℎ0392𝑔0.5ℙsubscriptℎ00.5ℙsubscriptℎ00.512\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\Big{(}39\sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}\sqrt{h_{0}}<39\sqrt{\frac% {2}{g}}\sqrt{0.5}\Big{)}=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\sqrt{h_{0}}<\sqrt{0.5})=% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(h_{0}<0.5)=\frac{1}{2},blackboard_P ( 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG < 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG square-root start_ARG 0.5 end_ARG ) = blackboard_P ( square-root start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG < square-root start_ARG 0.5 end_ARG ) = blackboard_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 0.5 ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ,

and

ℙ⁡(39⁢2g⁢h0<39⁢2g⁢49)=ℙ⁡(h0<49)=ℙ⁡(h0<49)=49≈0.4444.ℙ392𝑔subscriptℎ0392𝑔49ℙsubscriptℎ049ℙsubscriptℎ049490.4444\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(39\sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}\sqrt{h_{0}}<39\sqrt{\frac{% 2}{g}}\sqrt{\frac{4}{9}}\right)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\sqrt{h_{0}}<% \sqrt{\frac{4}{9}}\right)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(h_{0}<\frac{4}{9}% \right)=\frac{4}{9}\approx 0.4444.blackboard_P ( 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG < 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG end_ARG ) = blackboard_P ( square-root start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG < square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG end_ARG ) = blackboard_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG ) = divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG ≈ 0.4444 .

The reason for choosing 4949\frac{4}{9}divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG is that, in the solution of parts (i) and (ii), we have seen that the expectation of the total time that elapses before the ball stops moving is equal to the total time that elapses before a ball dropped from a height of 4949\frac{4}{9}divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG stops moving, that is, 𝔼⁡(39⁢2g⁢h0)=39⁢2g⁢49𝔼392𝑔subscriptℎ0392𝑔49\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left(39\sqrt{\frac{2}{g}}\sqrt{h_{0}}\right)=39\sqrt% {\frac{2}{g}}\sqrt{\frac{4}{9}}blackboard_E ( 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG ) = 39 square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 4 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG end_ARG. This also provides an example for the fact that given two random variables η𝜂\etaitalic_η and ζ𝜁\zetaitalic_ζ, it can happen that their expected values are equal, i.e., 𝔼⁡(η)=𝔼⁡(ζ)𝔼𝜂𝔼𝜁\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\eta)=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\zeta)blackboard_E ( italic_η ) = blackboard_E ( italic_ζ ), but ℙ⁡(η<ζ)≠12ℙ𝜂𝜁12\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\eta<\zeta)\neq\frac{1}{2}blackboard_P ( italic_η < italic_ζ ) ≠ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG.

(iv). The range of the random variable ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ is {0,1,2,…}012…\{0,1,2,\ldots\}{ 0 , 1 , 2 , … }, but we will check that ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ takes every positive even number with probability 00, and it will also turn out that there exists a natural number n0subscript𝑛0n_{0}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that the probability that ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ takes a value greater than n0subscript𝑛0n_{0}italic_n start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is 00.

Using the calculations before parts (i) and (ii), we have that ℙ⁡(ξ=0)=ℙ⁡(h0<0.1)=0.1ℙ𝜉0ℙsubscriptℎ00.10.1\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=0)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(h_{0}<0.1)=0.1blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = 0 ) = blackboard_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT < 0.1 ) = 0.1, furthermore,

ℙ⁡(ξ=1)ℙ𝜉1\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=1)blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = 1 ) =ℙ⁡(h0⩾0.1,v122⁢g<0.1)=ℙ⁡(h0⩾0.1,(0.95⁢v0)22⁢g<0.1)absentℙsubscriptℎ00.1superscriptsubscript𝑣122𝑔0.1ℙsubscriptℎ00.1superscript0.95subscript𝑣022𝑔0.1\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\Big{(}h_{0}\geqslant 0.1\,,\frac{v_{1}% ^{2}}{2g}<0.1\Big{)}=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\Big{(}h_{0}\geqslant 0.1\,,% \frac{(0.95v_{0})^{2}}{2g}<0.1\Big{)}= blackboard_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⩾ 0.1 , divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_g end_ARG < 0.1 ) = blackboard_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⩾ 0.1 , divide start_ARG ( 0.95 italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_g end_ARG < 0.1 )

Using that the inequality 0.10.952⁢(k+1)<10.1superscript0.952𝑘11\frac{0.1}{0.95^{2(k+1)}}<1divide start_ARG 0.1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 ( italic_k + 1 ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG < 1 holds if and only if

ln⁡(0.1)<2⁢(k+1)⁢ln⁡(0.95)⟺ln⁡(0.1)2⁢ln⁡(0.95)−1>k⟺k⩽21,formulae-sequence0.12𝑘10.95⟺formulae-sequence0.120.951𝑘⟺𝑘21\displaystyle\ln(0.1)<2(k+1)\ln(0.95)\quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad\frac{\ln(0.% 1)}{2\ln(0.95)}-1>k\quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad k\leqslant 21,roman_ln ( 0.1 ) < 2 ( italic_k + 1 ) roman_ln ( 0.95 ) ⟺ divide start_ARG roman_ln ( 0.1 ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 roman_ln ( 0.95 ) end_ARG - 1 > italic_k ⟺ italic_k ⩽ 21 ,

since k𝑘kitalic_k is an integer, and that the inequality 0.10.952⁢k<10.1superscript0.952𝑘1\frac{0.1}{0.95^{2k}}<1divide start_ARG 0.1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG < 1 holds if and only if

ln⁡(0.1)2⁢ln⁡(0.95)>k⟺k⩽22,formulae-sequence0.120.95𝑘⟺𝑘22\frac{\ln(0.1)}{2\ln(0.95)}>k\quad\Longleftrightarrow\quad k\leqslant 22,divide start_ARG roman_ln ( 0.1 ) end_ARG start_ARG 2 roman_ln ( 0.95 ) end_ARG > italic_k ⟺ italic_k ⩽ 22 ,

we get that for each k∈{1,2,…}𝑘12…k\in\{1,2,\ldots\}italic_k ∈ { 1 , 2 , … },

ℙ⁡(ξ=2⁢k+1)={0.1⁢(10.952−1)⁢0.95−2⁢kif k∈{1,2,…,21},1−0.10.952⁢kif k=22,0if k⩾23.ℙ𝜉2𝑘1cases0.11superscript0.9521superscript0.952𝑘if k∈{1,2,…,21},10.1superscript0.952𝑘if k=22,0if k⩾23.\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=2k+1)=\begin{cases}0.1\left(\frac{1% }{0.95^{2}}-1\right)0.95^{-2k}&\text{if \ $k\in\{1,2,\ldots,21\}$,}\\ 1-\frac{0.1}{0.95^{2k}}&\text{if \ $k=22$,}\\ 0&\text{if \ $k\geqslant 23$.}\end{cases}blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = 2 italic_k + 1 ) = { start_ROW start_CELL 0.1 ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG - 1 ) 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_CELL start_CELL if italic_k ∈ { 1 , 2 , … , 21 } , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 - divide start_ARG 0.1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG end_CELL start_CELL if italic_k = 22 , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL if italic_k ⩾ 23 . end_CELL end_ROW

All in all, the distribution of ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ takes the form

ℙ⁡(ξ=0)=0.1,ℙ𝜉00.1\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=0)=0.1,blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = 0 ) = 0.1 ,
ℙ⁡(ξ=2⁢k+1)=0.1⁢(10.952−1)⁢0.95−2⁢k=0.95−2⁢k⁢ℙ⁡(ξ=1),k∈{0,1,2,…,21},formulae-sequenceℙ𝜉2𝑘10.11superscript0.9521superscript0.952𝑘superscript0.952𝑘ℙ𝜉1𝑘012…21\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=2k+1)=0.1\left(\frac{1}{0.95^{2}}-1% \right)0.95^{-2k}=0.95^{-2k}\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=1),\qquad k\in\{0,1,% 2,\ldots,21\},blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = 2 italic_k + 1 ) = 0.1 ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG - 1 ) 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = 1 ) , italic_k ∈ { 0 , 1 , 2 , … , 21 } ,
ℙ⁡(ξ=45)=1−0.10.9544≈0.04465.ℙ𝜉4510.1superscript0.95440.04465\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=45)=1-\frac{0.1}{0.95^{44}}\approx 0% .04465.blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = 45 ) = 1 - divide start_ARG 0.1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 44 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ≈ 0.04465 .

One can check that the given values are indeed a probability distribution, since the given values are trivially nonnegative and

0.1+∑k=0210.1⁢(10.952−1)⁢0.95−2⁢k+1−0.10.95440.1superscriptsubscript𝑘0210.11superscript0.9521superscript0.952𝑘10.1superscript0.9544\displaystyle 0.1+\sum_{k=0}^{21}0.1\left(\frac{1}{0.95^{2}}-1\right)0.95^{-2k% }+1-\frac{0.1}{0.95^{44}}0.1 + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 21 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0.1 ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG - 1 ) 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 1 - divide start_ARG 0.1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 44 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG
=0.1+0.1⁢(10.952−1)⋅(0.95−2)22−10.95−2−1+1−0.10.9544=1.absent0.1⋅0.11superscript0.9521superscriptsuperscript0.952221superscript0.952110.1superscript0.95441\displaystyle\qquad=0.1+0.1\left(\frac{1}{0.95^{2}}-1\right)\cdot\frac{(0.95^{% -2})^{22}-1}{0.95^{-2}-1}+1-\frac{0.1}{0.95^{44}}=1.= 0.1 + 0.1 ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG - 1 ) ⋅ divide start_ARG ( 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 22 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_ARG + 1 - divide start_ARG 0.1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 44 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG = 1 .

This implies that the expectation of ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ is

𝔼⁡(ξ)𝔼𝜉\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi)blackboard_E ( italic_ξ ) =0⋅0.1+∑k=021(2⁢k+1)⋅0.1⁢(10.952−1)⁢0.95−2⁢k+45⁢(1−0.10.9544)absent⋅00.1superscriptsubscript𝑘021⋅2𝑘10.11superscript0.9521superscript0.952𝑘4510.1superscript0.9544\displaystyle=0\cdot 0.1+\sum_{k=0}^{21}(2k+1)\cdot 0.1\left(\frac{1}{0.95^{2}% }-1\right)0.95^{-2k}+45\left(1-\frac{0.1}{0.95^{44}}\right)= 0 ⋅ 0.1 + ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 21 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 italic_k + 1 ) ⋅ 0.1 ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG - 1 ) 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 45 ( 1 - divide start_ARG 0.1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 44 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG )
=44.9−4.40.9544+0.2⁢1−0.9520.952⁢∑k=121k⋅0.95−2⁢k≈27.35.absent44.94.4superscript0.95440.21superscript0.952superscript0.952superscriptsubscript𝑘121⋅𝑘superscript0.952𝑘27.35\displaystyle=44.9-\frac{4.4}{0.95^{44}}+0.2\frac{1-0.95^{2}}{0.95^{2}}\sum_{k% =1}^{21}k\cdot 0.95^{-2k}\approx 27.35.= 44.9 - divide start_ARG 4.4 end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 44 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + 0.2 divide start_ARG 1 - 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_k = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 21 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_k ⋅ 0.95 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 2 italic_k end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≈ 27.35 .

Note that the function {0,1,…,21}∋k↦ℙ⁡(ξ=2⁢k+1)contains01…21𝑘maps-toℙ𝜉2𝑘1\{0,1,\ldots,21\}\ni k\mapsto\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=2k+1){ 0 , 1 , … , 21 } ∋ italic_k ↦ blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = 2 italic_k + 1 ) is strictly increasing, however, the function {0,1,…,22}∋k↦ℙ⁡(ξ=2⁢k+1)contains01…22𝑘maps-toℙ𝜉2𝑘1\{0,1,\ldots,22\}\ni k\mapsto\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=2k+1){ 0 , 1 , … , 22 } ∋ italic_k ↦ blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = 2 italic_k + 1 ) is not strictly increasing, since ℙ⁡(ξ=43)≈0.09315ℙ𝜉430.09315\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=43)\approx 0.09315blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = 43 ) ≈ 0.09315, which is greater than ℙ⁡(ξ=45)≈0.04465ℙ𝜉450.04465\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=45)\approx 0.04465blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = 45 ) ≈ 0.04465. Remark also that the (unique) maximum of the probabilities ℙ⁡(ξ=0)ℙ𝜉0\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=0)blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = 0 ) and ℙ⁡(ξ=2⁢k+1)ℙ𝜉2𝑘1\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=2k+1)blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = 2 italic_k + 1 ), k∈{0,1,…,22}𝑘01…22k\in\{0,1,\ldots,22\}italic_k ∈ { 0 , 1 , … , 22 } is equal to ℙ⁡(ξ=0)=0.1ℙ𝜉00.1\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=0)=0.1blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = 0 ) = 0.1, yielding that the mode of the distribution of ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ is 00. □□\Box□

The next exercise is a randomized version of Exercise 2, Round I, Category I at the Sándor Mikola Physics Competition (2023) (see [4]) in the sense that we consider the so-called collision number appearing in the exercise as a random variable. We also point out that the deterministic counterparts of the questions that we consider in our next exercise are not included in the exercise at the Sándor Mikola Physics Competition.

2.4 Exercise.

According to the International Tennis Federation, a tennis ball is considered standard if, when dropped on concrete from a height of 254 cm, the rebound height falls between 135 cm and 147 cm. By collision number, by definition, we mean the ratio of the rebound and landing speeds when a tennis ball is dropped on concrete from a height of 254 cm. The companies A and B produce tennis balls. In case of Company A, the collision number is a random variable with uniform distribution on the interval [0.7,0.8]0.70.8[0.7,0.8][ 0.7 , 0.8 ], and in case of Company B, it an absolutely continuous random variable with a density function

fB⁢(x)={200⁢x−140if x∈[0.7,0.8],0otherwise.subscript𝑓𝐵𝑥cases200𝑥140if x∈[0.7,0.8],0otherwise.f_{B}(x)=\begin{cases}200x-140&\text{if $x\in[0.7,0.8]$,}\\ 0&\text{otherwise.}\end{cases}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = { start_ROW start_CELL 200 italic_x - 140 end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x ∈ [ 0.7 , 0.8 ] , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL otherwise. end_CELL end_ROW
  1. (i)

    We drop a tennis ball produced by Company A on concrete from a height of 254 cm. How high is the bounce back expected to be? Answer the same question for a tennis ball produced by Company B.

  2. (ii)

    What is the probability that a tennis ball produced by Company A is standard? Answer the same question for a tennis ball produced by Company B.

  3. (iii)

    Company A and B send us 40 and 60 tennis balls, respectively, as a promotional gift. We mix the 100 tennis balls, we randomly choose one of them and then, by dropping it on concrete from a height of 254 cm, we classify it standard. What is the probability that the tennis ball was produced by company A?

Solution. If we drop a ball from a height of hlsubscriptℎ𝑙h_{l}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then it has velocity vl=2⁢g⁢hlsubscript𝑣𝑙2𝑔subscriptℎ𝑙v_{l}=\sqrt{2gh_{l}}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = square-root start_ARG 2 italic_g italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG when it hits the ground. Furthermore, if its rebounce velocity is vfsubscript𝑣𝑓v_{f}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, then, for the rebounce height denoted by hfsubscriptℎ𝑓h_{f}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, it holds that vf=2⁢g⁢hfsubscript𝑣𝑓2𝑔subscriptℎ𝑓v_{f}=\sqrt{2gh_{f}}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = square-root start_ARG 2 italic_g italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG.

With these notations, the collision number takes the form

vfvl=2⁢g⁢hf2⁢g⋅2.54=hf2.54.subscript𝑣𝑓subscript𝑣𝑙2𝑔subscriptℎ𝑓⋅2𝑔2.54subscriptℎ𝑓2.54\frac{v_{f}}{v_{l}}=\frac{\sqrt{2gh_{f}}}{\sqrt{2g\cdot 2.54}}=\sqrt{\frac{h_{% f}}{2.54}}.divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 italic_g italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 italic_g ⋅ 2.54 end_ARG end_ARG = square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 2.54 end_ARG end_ARG .

In what follows, we denote the collision number by ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ, i.e., ξ:=vfvlassign𝜉subscript𝑣𝑓subscript𝑣𝑙\xi:=\frac{v_{f}}{v_{l}}italic_ξ := divide start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG. Then the rebounce height is hf=2.54⋅ξ2subscriptℎ𝑓⋅2.54superscript𝜉2h_{f}=2.54\cdot\xi^{2}italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 2.54 ⋅ italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

(i). In case of Company A, ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ is uniformly distributed on the interval [0.7,0.8]0.70.8[0.7,0.8][ 0.7 , 0.8 ], and hence we have that

𝔼⁡(hf)=2.54⁢𝔼⁡(ξ2)=2.54⁢∫0.70.8x2⁢10.1⁢dx=25.43⁢(0.83−0.73)≈1.431,𝔼subscriptℎ𝑓2.54𝔼superscript𝜉22.54superscriptsubscript0.70.8superscript𝑥210.1differential-d𝑥25.43superscript0.83superscript0.731.431\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(h_{f})=2.54\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(% \xi^{2})=2.54\int_{0.7}^{0.8}x^{2}\frac{1}{0.1}\,\mathrm{d}x=\frac{25.4}{3}(0.% 8^{3}-0.7^{3})\approx 1.431,blackboard_E ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = 2.54 blackboard_E ( italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 2.54 ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0.7 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0.8 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 0.1 end_ARG roman_d italic_x = divide start_ARG 25.4 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ( 0.8 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 0.7 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≈ 1.431 ,

i.e., a tennis ball produced by Company A rebounds to the expected height of approximately 143.1 cm dropped from a height of 254 cm.

In case of Company B, ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ is an absolutely continuous random variable with a density function fBsubscript𝑓𝐵f_{B}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then we get that

𝔼⁡(hf)𝔼subscriptℎ𝑓\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(h_{f})blackboard_E ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =2.54⁢𝔼⁡(ξ2)=2.54⁢∫0.70.8x2⁢(200⁢x−140)⁢dx=2.54⁢∫0.70.8(200⁢x3−140⁢x2)⁢dxabsent2.54𝔼superscript𝜉22.54superscriptsubscript0.70.8superscript𝑥2200𝑥140differential-d𝑥2.54superscriptsubscript0.70.8200superscript𝑥3140superscript𝑥2differential-d𝑥\displaystyle=2.54\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi^{2})=2.54\int_{0.7}^{0.8}x^{2}% (200x-140)\,\mathrm{d}x=2.54\int_{0.7}^{0.8}(200x^{3}-140x^{2})\,\mathrm{d}x= 2.54 blackboard_E ( italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) = 2.54 ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0.7 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0.8 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 200 italic_x - 140 ) roman_d italic_x = 2.54 ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0.7 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 0.8 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 200 italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 140 italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) roman_d italic_x
=2.54⁢(50⁢(0.84−0.74)−1403⁢(0.83−0.73))≈1.494,absent2.5450superscript0.84superscript0.741403superscript0.83superscript0.731.494\displaystyle=2.54\Big{(}50(0.8^{4}-0.7^{4})-\frac{140}{3}(0.8^{3}-0.7^{3})% \Big{)}\approx 1.494,= 2.54 ( 50 ( 0.8 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 0.7 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - divide start_ARG 140 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ( 0.8 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 0.7 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 3 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ) ≈ 1.494 ,

i.e., a tennis ball produced by Company B rebounds to the expected height of approximately 1.494 cm dropped from a height of 254 cm.

(ii). Using that

{a tennis ball is standard}={hf∈(1.35,1.47)},a tennis ball is standardsubscriptℎ𝑓1.351.47\Big{\{}\text{a tennis ball is standard}\Big{\}}=\{h_{f}\in(1.35,1.47)\},{ a tennis ball is standard } = { italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ ( 1.35 , 1.47 ) } ,

we get that, in case of Company A, the probability that a tennis ball is standard is

ℙ⁡(hf∈(1.35,1.47))ℙsubscriptℎ𝑓1.351.47\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(h_{f}\in(1.35,1.47))blackboard_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ ( 1.35 , 1.47 ) ) =ℙ⁡(1.35<2.54⋅ξ2<1.47)=ℙ⁡(135254<ξ<147254)absentℙ1.35⋅2.54superscript𝜉21.47ℙ135254𝜉147254\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(1.35<2.54\cdot\xi^{2}<1.47)=% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\Big{(}\sqrt{\frac{135}{254}}<\xi<\sqrt{\frac{147}{25% 4}}\Big{)}= blackboard_P ( 1.35 < 2.54 ⋅ italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < 1.47 ) = blackboard_P ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 135 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG < italic_ξ < square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 147 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG )
=147254−1352540.8−0.7≈0.3171,absent1472541352540.80.70.3171\displaystyle=\frac{\sqrt{\frac{147}{254}}-\sqrt{\frac{135}{254}}}{0.8-0.7}% \approx 0.3171,= divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 147 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG - square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 135 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 0.8 - 0.7 end_ARG ≈ 0.3171 ,

and, in case of Company B, is

ℙ⁡(hf∈(1.35,1.47))ℙsubscriptℎ𝑓1.351.47\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(h_{f}\in(1.35,1.47))blackboard_P ( italic_h start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ ( 1.35 , 1.47 ) ) =ℙ⁡(1.35<2.54⋅ξ2<1.47)=ℙ⁡(135254<ξ<147254)absentℙ1.35⋅2.54superscript𝜉21.47ℙ135254𝜉147254\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(1.35<2.54\cdot\xi^{2}<1.47)=% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\Big{(}\sqrt{\frac{135}{254}}<\xi<\sqrt{\frac{147}{25% 4}}\Big{)}= blackboard_P ( 1.35 < 2.54 ⋅ italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT < 1.47 ) = blackboard_P ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 135 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG < italic_ξ < square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 147 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG )
=∫135254147254(200⁢x−140)⁢dx=1200254−140⁢(147254−135254)≈0.2847.absentsuperscriptsubscript135254147254200𝑥140differential-d𝑥12002541401472541352540.2847\displaystyle=\int_{\sqrt{\frac{135}{254}}}^{\sqrt{\frac{147}{254}}}(200x-140)% \,\mathrm{d}x=\frac{1200}{254}-140\left(\sqrt{\frac{147}{254}}-\sqrt{\frac{135% }{254}}\right)\approx 0.2847.= ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 135 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 147 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 200 italic_x - 140 ) roman_d italic_x = divide start_ARG 1200 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG - 140 ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 147 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG - square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 135 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG ) ≈ 0.2847 .

(iii). Let us introduce the following events

GA:={the chosen tennis ball was produced by Company A},assignsubscript𝐺𝐴the chosen tennis ball was produced by Company A\displaystyle G_{A}:=\Big{\{}\text{the chosen tennis ball was produced by % Company A}\Big{\}},italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := { the chosen tennis ball was produced by Company A } ,
GB:={the chosen tennis ball was produced by Company B},assignsubscript𝐺𝐵the chosen tennis ball was produced by Company B\displaystyle G_{B}:=\Big{\{}\text{the chosen tennis ball was produced by % Company B}\Big{\}},italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := { the chosen tennis ball was produced by Company B } ,
S:={the chosen tennis ball is standard}.assign𝑆the chosen tennis ball is standard\displaystyle S:=\Big{\{}\text{the chosen tennis ball is standard}\Big{\}}.italic_S := { the chosen tennis ball is standard } .

We need to calculate the conditional probability ℙ⁡(GA|S)ℙconditionalsubscript𝐺𝐴𝑆\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(G_{A}\,|\,S)blackboard_P ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S ). Since GAsubscript𝐺𝐴G_{A}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and GBsubscript𝐺𝐵G_{B}italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are disjoint events with positive probability and their union is the whole sample space, one can apply Bayes’ theorem (see (A.1)) and we get that

ℙ⁡(GA|S)ℙconditionalsubscript𝐺𝐴𝑆\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(G_{A}\,|\,S)blackboard_P ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S ) =ℙ⁡(S|GA)⁢ℙ⁡(GA)ℙ⁡(S|GA)⁢ℙ⁡(GA)+ℙ⁡(S|GB)⁢ℙ⁡(GB)absentℙconditional𝑆subscript𝐺𝐴ℙsubscript𝐺𝐴ℙconditional𝑆subscript𝐺𝐴ℙsubscript𝐺𝐴ℙconditional𝑆subscript𝐺𝐵ℙsubscript𝐺𝐵\displaystyle=\frac{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(S\,|\,G_{A})\operatorname{% \mathbb{P}}(G_{A})}{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(S\,|\,G_{A})\operatorname{% \mathbb{P}}(G_{A})+\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(S\,|\,G_{B})\operatorname{\mathbb% {P}}(G_{B})}= divide start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_S | italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) blackboard_P ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_S | italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) blackboard_P ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + blackboard_P ( italic_S | italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) blackboard_P ( italic_G start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG
=147254−1352540.8−0.7⋅0.4147254−1352540.8−0.7⋅0.4+(1200254−140⁢(147254−135254))⋅0.6absent⋅1472541352540.80.70.4⋅1472541352540.80.70.4⋅12002541401472541352540.6\displaystyle=\frac{\frac{\sqrt{\frac{147}{254}}-\sqrt{\frac{135}{254}}}{0.8-0% .7}\cdot 0.4}{\frac{\sqrt{\frac{147}{254}}-\sqrt{\frac{135}{254}}}{0.8-0.7}% \cdot 0.4+\left(\frac{1200}{254}-140\left(\sqrt{\frac{147}{254}}-\sqrt{\frac{1% 35}{254}}\right)\right)\cdot 0.6}= divide start_ARG divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 147 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG - square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 135 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 0.8 - 0.7 end_ARG ⋅ 0.4 end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 147 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG - square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 135 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 0.8 - 0.7 end_ARG ⋅ 0.4 + ( divide start_ARG 1200 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG - 140 ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 147 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG - square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 135 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG ) ) ⋅ 0.6 end_ARG
=4⁢(147254−135254)720254−80⁢(147254−135254)≈0.4261.absent4147254135254720254801472541352540.4261\displaystyle=\frac{4\left(\sqrt{\frac{147}{254}}-\sqrt{\frac{135}{254}}\right% )}{\frac{720}{254}-80\left(\sqrt{\frac{147}{254}}-\sqrt{\frac{135}{254}}\right% )}\approx 0.4261.= divide start_ARG 4 ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 147 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG - square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 135 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG 720 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG - 80 ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 147 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG - square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 135 end_ARG start_ARG 254 end_ARG end_ARG ) end_ARG ≈ 0.4261 .

□□\Box□

Part (i) of the next Exercise 2.5 is a randomized version of Exercise 1, Round II, Category III at the Sándor Mikola Physics Competition (2023) (see [4]) in the sense that the precise theoretical value of the gravity of Earth is considered to be a random value. Note that this kind of normalization is different from the ones in Exercises 2.1-2.3 in the sense that the uncertainty in a system’s parameter is studied in Exercise 2.5 instead of the uncertainty in some of the inputs of a dynamical system.

2.5 Exercise.

Let g𝑔gitalic_g denote the (theoretical) value of the gravity of Earth and let ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ be a uniformly distributed random variable on the interval [−1,1]11[-1,1][ - 1 , 1 ]. What is the expectation of the relative error that we make if the gravity of Earth is taken to be (g+ξ)𝑔𝜉(g+\xi)( italic_g + italic_ξ ) instead of the theoretical value g𝑔gitalic_g and

  • (i)

    we calculate the distance traveled by a free-falling body over a given period of time?

  • (ii)

    we calculate the time needed by a free-falling body to travel a given distance?

Solution. It is known that a free-falling body travels a distance g2⁢t2𝑔2superscript𝑡2\frac{g}{2}t^{2}divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over a given period of time t𝑡titalic_t, and it needs a time 2⁢hg2ℎ𝑔\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG to travel a given distance hℎhitalic_h.

(i). The relative error of the distances over a given time period t𝑡titalic_t (with respect to the distance calculated by the theoretical value of g𝑔gitalic_g) is

g+ξ2⁢t2−g2⁢t2g2⁢t2=ξg.𝑔𝜉2superscript𝑡2𝑔2superscript𝑡2𝑔2superscript𝑡2𝜉𝑔\frac{\frac{g+\xi}{2}t^{2}-\frac{g}{2}t^{2}}{\frac{g}{2}t^{2}}=\frac{\xi}{g}.divide start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_g + italic_ξ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG = divide start_ARG italic_ξ end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG .

Consequently, the expected value of ξg𝜉𝑔\frac{\xi}{g}divide start_ARG italic_ξ end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG is

𝔼⁡(ξg)=1g⁢𝔼⁡(ξ)=1g⋅−1+12=0,𝔼𝜉𝑔1𝑔𝔼𝜉⋅1𝑔1120\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left(\frac{\xi}{g}\right)=\frac{1}{g}\operatorname{% \mathbb{E}}(\xi)=\frac{1}{g}\cdot\frac{-1+1}{2}=0,blackboard_E ( divide start_ARG italic_ξ end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG blackboard_E ( italic_ξ ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG - 1 + 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG = 0 ,

that is, the expected value of the relative error in question is 00.

(ii). The relative error of the times needed for travelling a given distance hℎhitalic_h (with respect to the time calculated by the theoretical value of g𝑔gitalic_g) is

2⁢hg+ξ−2⁢hg2⁢hg=gg+ξ−1.2ℎ𝑔𝜉2ℎ𝑔2ℎ𝑔𝑔𝑔𝜉1\displaystyle\frac{\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g+\xi}}-\sqrt{\frac{2h}{g}}}{\sqrt{\frac{2h% }{g}}}=\sqrt{\frac{g}{g+\xi}}-1.divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g + italic_ξ end_ARG end_ARG - square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 2 italic_h end_ARG start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG end_ARG = square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG italic_g + italic_ξ end_ARG end_ARG - 1 .

Consequently, we get that

𝔼⁡(gg+ξ−1)=g⁢𝔼⁡(1g+ξ)−1=g⁢∫−111g+x⋅12⁢dx−1𝔼𝑔𝑔𝜉1𝑔𝔼1𝑔𝜉1𝑔superscriptsubscript11⋅1𝑔𝑥12differential-d𝑥1\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left(\sqrt{\frac{g}{g+\xi}}-1\right)=% \sqrt{g}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{g+\xi}}\right)-1=\sqrt{g% }\int_{-1}^{1}\frac{1}{\sqrt{g+x}}\cdot\frac{1}{2}\,\mathrm{d}x-1blackboard_E ( square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_g end_ARG start_ARG italic_g + italic_ξ end_ARG end_ARG - 1 ) = square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG blackboard_E ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_g + italic_ξ end_ARG end_ARG ) - 1 = square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_g + italic_x end_ARG end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG roman_d italic_x - 1
=g⁢(g+1−g−1)−1=2⁢gg+1+g−1−1=2⁢g−g+1−g−1g+1+g−1.absent𝑔𝑔1𝑔112𝑔𝑔1𝑔112𝑔𝑔1𝑔1𝑔1𝑔1\displaystyle=\sqrt{g}(\sqrt{g+1}-\sqrt{g-1})-1=\frac{2\sqrt{g}}{\sqrt{g+1}+% \sqrt{g-1}}-1=\frac{2\sqrt{g}-\sqrt{g+1}-\sqrt{g-1}}{\sqrt{g+1}+\sqrt{g-1}}.= square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG ( square-root start_ARG italic_g + 1 end_ARG - square-root start_ARG italic_g - 1 end_ARG ) - 1 = divide start_ARG 2 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_g + 1 end_ARG + square-root start_ARG italic_g - 1 end_ARG end_ARG - 1 = divide start_ARG 2 square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG - square-root start_ARG italic_g + 1 end_ARG - square-root start_ARG italic_g - 1 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_g + 1 end_ARG + square-root start_ARG italic_g - 1 end_ARG end_ARG .

This expected value is positive, since the function [0,∞)∋x↦xcontains0𝑥maps-to𝑥[0,\infty)\ni x\mapsto\sqrt{x}[ 0 , ∞ ) ∋ italic_x ↦ square-root start_ARG italic_x end_ARG is strictly concave, and hence

g+1+g−12>12⁢(g+1)+12⁢(g−1)=g.𝑔1𝑔1212𝑔112𝑔1𝑔\frac{\sqrt{g+1}+\sqrt{g-1}}{2}>\sqrt{\frac{1}{2}(g+1)+\frac{1}{2}(g-1)}=\sqrt% {g}.divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG italic_g + 1 end_ARG + square-root start_ARG italic_g - 1 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG > square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_g + 1 ) + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( italic_g - 1 ) end_ARG = square-root start_ARG italic_g end_ARG .

In our present paper, the theoretical value of g𝑔gitalic_g is considered to be 9.819.819.819.81, and hence the expected value of the relative error in question is approximately 0.0013050.0013050.0013050.001305.

Finally, we call the attention to the fact that, in part (i), the expected value of the relative error does not depend on the theoretical value of g𝑔gitalic_g, while in part (ii), it does. □□\Box□

3 A stochastic approach in statics

In this section, we demonstrate our method for incorporating a stochastic point of view into physics exercises of mathematics education by presenting exercises for statics. In them, we randomize the geometry of the static problem, for example, the shape of a plate or the position of some of the pinning points of a plate. To avoid technicalities, we choose uniform distributions as the distributions of the random inputs. Altogether, we present three exercises in this section.

3.1 Exercise.

A square piece of homogeneous sheet metal of side length 1 m and mass m𝑚mitalic_m kg is bent in the following way: on one side, at a point chosen at a distance of 1414\frac{1}{4}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG from one of the vertices, a perpendicular is set on that side, and we bend the metal sheet along this perpendicular in a way that the angle between the two pieces is uniformly distributed on the interval (0,π2)0𝜋2(0,\frac{\pi}{2})( 0 , divide start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ). We place the bent plate with its smaller part on a horizontal surface, and then release it.

  • (i)

    What is the probability that it does not fall over?

  • (ii)

    What is the probability that the perpendicular projection of the center of gravity of the larger part of the bent plate falls on the smaller part of the bent plate given that the bent plate does not fall over?

Solution. Figure 6 shows a planar section of the bent plate corresponding to a plane, which is perpendicular to the bending line at a point (denoted by T𝑇Titalic_T).

Let α𝛼\alphaitalic_α denote the angle between the two pieces. Then α𝛼\alphaitalic_α is a random variable with uniform distribution on the interval (0,π2)0𝜋2(0,\frac{\pi}{2})( 0 , divide start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ). Let S1subscript𝑆1S_{1}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and S2subscript𝑆2S_{2}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the centers of gravity of the larger and smaller parts of the plate, respectively, and let R𝑅Ritalic_R be the endpoint different from T𝑇Titalic_T of the planar section of the smaller part. Let

𝑭1:=[0−m⁢g⁢34]and𝑭2:=[0−m⁢g⁢14].formulae-sequenceassignsubscript𝑭1matrix0𝑚𝑔34andassignsubscript𝑭2matrix0𝑚𝑔14{\boldsymbol{F}}_{1}:=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ -mg\frac{3}{4}\\ \end{bmatrix}\qquad\text{and}\qquad{\boldsymbol{F}}_{2}:=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ -mg\frac{1}{4}\\ \end{bmatrix}.bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL - italic_m italic_g divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] and bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL - italic_m italic_g divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] .

(i). Then {the bent plate does not fall over}=A∪Bthe bent plate does not fall over𝐴𝐵\{\text{the bent plate does not fall over}\}=A\cup B{ the bent plate does not fall over } = italic_A ∪ italic_B, where the events A𝐴Aitalic_A and B𝐵Bitalic_B are defined by

A:={the perpendicular projection of S1 falls on the section T⁢R},assign𝐴the perpendicular projection of S1 falls on the section T⁢RA:=\Big{\{}\text{the perpendicular projection of $S_{1}$ falls on the section % $TR$}\Big{\}},italic_A := { the perpendicular projection of italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT falls on the section italic_T italic_R } ,

and

B:=assign𝐵absent\displaystyle B:=italic_B := {the perpendicular projection of S1 does not fall on the section T⁢R}the perpendicular projection of S1 does not fall on the section T⁢R\displaystyle\Big{\{}\text{the perpendicular projection of $S_{1}$ does not % fall on the section $TR$}\Big{\}}{ the perpendicular projection of italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT does not fall on the section italic_T italic_R }
∩{the magnitude of the moment of force of 𝑭2 with respect to R is greater than\displaystyle\cap\Big{\{}\text{the magnitude of the moment of force of ${% \boldsymbol{F}}_{2}$ with respect to $R$ is greater than }∩ { the magnitude of the moment of force of bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with respect to italic_R is greater than
or equal to the magnitude of the moment of force of 𝑭1 with respect to R}.\displaystyle\phantom{\cap\Big{\{}\Big{\{}}\text{or equal to the magnitude of % the moment of force of ${\boldsymbol{F}}_{1}$ with respect to $R$}\Big{\}}.or equal to the magnitude of the moment of force of bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with respect to italic_R } .

Then the events A𝐴Aitalic_A and B𝐵Bitalic_B are disjoint, and using that the distance between the perpendicular projection of S1subscript𝑆1S_{1}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the point T𝑇Titalic_T is 38⁢cos⁡(α)38𝛼\frac{3}{8}\cos(\alpha)divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG roman_cos ( italic_α ) and the length of the section T⁢R𝑇𝑅TRitalic_T italic_R is 1414\frac{1}{4}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG, we get that

A={38⁢cos⁡(α)⩽14},𝐴38𝛼14\displaystyle A=\left\{\frac{3}{8}\cos(\alpha)\leqslant\frac{1}{4}\right\},italic_A = { divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG roman_cos ( italic_α ) ⩽ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG } ,
B={38⁢cos⁡(α)>14}∩{m⁢g⁢14⋅18⩾m⁢g⁢34⋅(38⁢cos⁡(α)−14)}.𝐵38𝛼14⋅𝑚𝑔1418⋅𝑚𝑔3438𝛼14\displaystyle B=\left\{\frac{3}{8}\cos(\alpha)>\frac{1}{4}\right\}\cap\left\{% mg\frac{1}{4}\cdot\frac{1}{8}\geqslant mg\frac{3}{4}\cdot\left(\frac{3}{8}\cos% (\alpha)-\frac{1}{4}\right)\right\}.italic_B = { divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG roman_cos ( italic_α ) > divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG } ∩ { italic_m italic_g divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG ⩾ italic_m italic_g divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ⋅ ( divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG roman_cos ( italic_α ) - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ) } .

Consequently, we have that A={cos⁡(α)⩽23}𝐴𝛼23A=\Big{\{}\cos(\alpha)\leqslant\frac{2}{3}\Big{\}}italic_A = { roman_cos ( italic_α ) ⩽ divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG } and

B𝐵\displaystyle Bitalic_B ={cos⁡(α)>23}∩{124⩾38⁢cos⁡(α)−14}={cos⁡(α)>23}∩{cos⁡(α)⩽79}absent𝛼2312438𝛼14𝛼23𝛼79\displaystyle=\left\{\cos(\alpha)>\frac{2}{3}\right\}\cap\left\{\frac{1}{24}% \geqslant\frac{3}{8}\cos(\alpha)-\frac{1}{4}\right\}=\left\{\cos(\alpha)>\frac% {2}{3}\right\}\cap\left\{\cos(\alpha)\leqslant\frac{7}{9}\right\}= { roman_cos ( italic_α ) > divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG } ∩ { divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 24 end_ARG ⩾ divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG roman_cos ( italic_α ) - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG } = { roman_cos ( italic_α ) > divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG } ∩ { roman_cos ( italic_α ) ⩽ divide start_ARG 7 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG }
={23<cos⁡(α)⩽79}.absent23𝛼79\displaystyle=\left\{\frac{2}{3}<\cos(\alpha)\leqslant\frac{7}{9}\right\}.= { divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG < roman_cos ( italic_α ) ⩽ divide start_ARG 7 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG } .

Hence {the bent plate does not fall over}={cos⁡(α)⩽79}the bent plate does not fall over𝛼79\{\text{the bent plate does not fall over}\}=\{\cos(\alpha)\leqslant\frac{7}{9}\}{ the bent plate does not fall over } = { roman_cos ( italic_α ) ⩽ divide start_ARG 7 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG }. Here the inequality cos⁡(α)⩽79𝛼79\cos(\alpha)\leqslant\frac{7}{9}roman_cos ( italic_α ) ⩽ divide start_ARG 7 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG, α∈(0,π2)𝛼0𝜋2\alpha\in(0,\frac{\pi}{2})italic_α ∈ ( 0 , divide start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) holds if and only if α∈[α0,π2)𝛼subscript𝛼0𝜋2\alpha\in[\alpha_{0},\frac{\pi}{2})italic_α ∈ [ italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , divide start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ), where α0∈(0,π2)subscript𝛼00𝜋2\alpha_{0}\in(0,\frac{\pi}{2})italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ ( 0 , divide start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) is the unique value for which cos⁡(α0)=79subscript𝛼079\cos(\alpha_{0})=\frac{7}{9}roman_cos ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 7 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG, i.e., α0=arccos⁡(79)≈0.6797subscript𝛼0790.6797\alpha_{0}=\arccos\left(\frac{7}{9}\right)\approx 0.6797italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_arccos ( divide start_ARG 7 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG ) ≈ 0.6797. Consequently, we have

{the bent plate does not fall over}=A∪B={α0⩽α<π2},the bent plate does not fall over𝐴𝐵subscript𝛼0𝛼𝜋2\{\text{the bent plate does not fall over}\}=A\cup B=\left\{\alpha_{0}% \leqslant\alpha<\frac{\pi}{2}\right\},{ the bent plate does not fall over } = italic_A ∪ italic_B = { italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⩽ italic_α < divide start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG } ,

and note that the angle α0subscript𝛼0\alpha_{0}italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the minimum of those angles in (0,π2)0𝜋2(0,\frac{\pi}{2})( 0 , divide start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) for which the bent plate is in equilibrium, and it holds that

m⁢g⁢14⋅18=m⁢g⁢34⋅(38⁢cos⁡(α0)−14).⋅𝑚𝑔1418⋅𝑚𝑔3438subscript𝛼014mg\frac{1}{4}\cdot\frac{1}{8}=mg\frac{3}{4}\cdot\left(\frac{3}{8}\cos(\alpha_{% 0})-\frac{1}{4}\right).italic_m italic_g divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG = italic_m italic_g divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ⋅ ( divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG roman_cos ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ) .

Therefore, we get that

ℙ⁡({the bent plate does not fall over})=ℙ⁡(α0⩽α<π2)ℙthe bent plate does not fall overℙsubscript𝛼0𝛼𝜋2\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\{\text{the bent plate does not fall % over}\})=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\alpha_{0}\leqslant\alpha<\frac{\pi}{2% }\right)blackboard_P ( { the bent plate does not fall over } ) = blackboard_P ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⩽ italic_α < divide start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG )
=π2−α0π2=π2−arccos⁡(79)π2=1−2⁢arccos⁡(79)π≈0.5673.absent𝜋2subscript𝛼0𝜋2𝜋279𝜋21279𝜋0.5673\displaystyle\qquad\qquad=\frac{\frac{\pi}{2}-\alpha_{0}}{\frac{\pi}{2}}=\frac% {\frac{\pi}{2}-\arccos\left(\frac{7}{9}\right)}{\frac{\pi}{2}}=1-\frac{2% \arccos\left(\frac{7}{9}\right)}{\pi}\approx 0.5673.= divide start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG = divide start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - roman_arccos ( divide start_ARG 7 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG = 1 - divide start_ARG 2 roman_arccos ( divide start_ARG 7 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_π end_ARG ≈ 0.5673 .

(ii). Using the notations introduced in the solution of part (i), we need to calculate the conditional probability ℙ⁡(A|A∪B)ℙconditional𝐴𝐴𝐵\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A\,|\,A\cup B)blackboard_P ( italic_A | italic_A ∪ italic_B ). Since the events A𝐴Aitalic_A and B𝐵Bitalic_B are disjoint, we get that

ℙ⁡(A|A∪B)=ℙ⁡(A∩(A∪B))ℙ⁡(A∪B)=ℙ⁡(A)ℙ⁡(A∪B),ℙconditional𝐴𝐴𝐵ℙ𝐴𝐴𝐵ℙ𝐴𝐵ℙ𝐴ℙ𝐴𝐵\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A\,|\,A\cup B)=\frac{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A\cap% (A\cup B))}{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A\cup B)}=\frac{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}% }(A)}{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A\cup B)},blackboard_P ( italic_A | italic_A ∪ italic_B ) = divide start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_A ∩ ( italic_A ∪ italic_B ) ) end_ARG start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_A ∪ italic_B ) end_ARG = divide start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_A ) end_ARG start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_A ∪ italic_B ) end_ARG ,

where, by the solution of part (i),

ℙ⁡(A∪B)=1−2⁢arccos⁡(79)π.ℙ𝐴𝐵1279𝜋\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A\cup B)=1-\frac{2\arccos\left(\frac{7}{9}\right)}{% \pi}.blackboard_P ( italic_A ∪ italic_B ) = 1 - divide start_ARG 2 roman_arccos ( divide start_ARG 7 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_π end_ARG .

Furthermore, we have that

ℙ⁡(A)=ℙ⁡(38⁢cos⁡(α)⩽14)=ℙ⁡(cos⁡(α)⩽23).ℙ𝐴ℙ38𝛼14ℙ𝛼23\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\frac{3}{8}\cos(% \alpha)\leqslant\frac{1}{4}\right)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\cos(\alpha)% \leqslant\frac{2}{3}\right).blackboard_P ( italic_A ) = blackboard_P ( divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 8 end_ARG roman_cos ( italic_α ) ⩽ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ) = blackboard_P ( roman_cos ( italic_α ) ⩽ divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ) .

Here the inequality cos⁡(α)⩽23𝛼23\cos(\alpha)\leqslant\frac{2}{3}roman_cos ( italic_α ) ⩽ divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG, α∈(0,π2)𝛼0𝜋2\alpha\in(0,\frac{\pi}{2})italic_α ∈ ( 0 , divide start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) holds if and only if α∈[α1,π2)𝛼subscript𝛼1𝜋2\alpha\in[\alpha_{1},\frac{\pi}{2})italic_α ∈ [ italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , divide start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ), where α1∈(0,π2)subscript𝛼10𝜋2\alpha_{1}\in(0,\frac{\pi}{2})italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ ( 0 , divide start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) is the unique value for which cos⁡(α1)=23subscript𝛼123\cos(\alpha_{1})=\frac{2}{3}roman_cos ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG, i.e., α1=arccos⁡(23)≈0.8411subscript𝛼1230.8411\alpha_{1}=\arccos\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)\approx 0.8411italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_arccos ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ) ≈ 0.8411. Consequently, we obtain that

ℙ⁡(A)=ℙ⁡(α1⩽α<π2)=π2−α1π2=π2−arccos⁡(23)π2=1−2⁢arccos⁡(23)π≈0.4645.ℙ𝐴ℙsubscript𝛼1𝛼𝜋2𝜋2subscript𝛼1𝜋2𝜋223𝜋21223𝜋0.4645\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A)=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\alpha_{1}% \leqslant\alpha<\frac{\pi}{2}\right)=\frac{\frac{\pi}{2}-\alpha_{1}}{\frac{\pi% }{2}}=\frac{\frac{\pi}{2}-\arccos\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)}{\frac{\pi}{2}}=1-% \frac{2\arccos\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)}{\pi}\approx 0.4645.blackboard_P ( italic_A ) = blackboard_P ( italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ⩽ italic_α < divide start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ) = divide start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - italic_α start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG = divide start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - roman_arccos ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG = 1 - divide start_ARG 2 roman_arccos ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG italic_π end_ARG ≈ 0.4645 .

Then we have

ℙ⁡(A|A∪B)=π2−arccos⁡(23)π2−arccos⁡(79)≈0.8189.ℙconditional𝐴𝐴𝐵𝜋223𝜋2790.8189\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A\,|\,A\cup B)=\frac{\frac{\pi}{2}-% \arccos\left(\frac{2}{3}\right)}{\frac{\pi}{2}-\arccos\left(\frac{7}{9}\right)% }\approx 0.8189.blackboard_P ( italic_A | italic_A ∪ italic_B ) = divide start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - roman_arccos ( divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ) end_ARG start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_π end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG - roman_arccos ( divide start_ARG 7 end_ARG start_ARG 9 end_ARG ) end_ARG ≈ 0.8189 .

□□\Box□

The following exercise is a randomized version of Problem 2 in Section 7.5 in Szíki [8].

3.2 Exercise.

Let us consider a homogeneous prismatic beam of length 1 m and mass m𝑚mitalic_m kg, and its two endpoints and the centre point are denoted by A𝐴Aitalic_A, B𝐵Bitalic_B and S𝑆Sitalic_S, respectively. The beam is fixed by means of a pin support at its point A𝐴Aitalic_A, and of a roller support at a point chosen uniformly on the section S⁢B𝑆𝐵SBitalic_S italic_B (see Figure 7).

  • (i)

    Let us determine the expected values of the reaction forces at the two supporting points!

  • (ii)

    Are the expected values of the reaction forces calculated in part (i) equal to the reaction forces which correspond to the case when the beam is fixed by means of a pin support at its point A𝐴Aitalic_A, and of a roller support at the bisection point of the section S⁢B𝑆𝐵SBitalic_S italic_B? Why is there no contradiction compared to the result obtained in part (i)?

Solution. (i). Let C𝐶Citalic_C and ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ denote the point corresponding to the roller support and the length of the section S⁢C𝑆𝐶SCitalic_S italic_C, respectively. Due to the assumptions, ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ is a random variable having uniform distribution on the interval [0,12]012[0,\frac{1}{2}][ 0 , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ]. The reaction forces at the points A𝐴Aitalic_A and C𝐶Citalic_C are denoted by 𝑭A=[FA,x,FA,y]⊤subscript𝑭𝐴superscriptsubscript𝐹𝐴𝑥subscript𝐹𝐴𝑦top{\boldsymbol{F}}_{A}=[F_{A,x},F_{A,y}]^{\top}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 𝑭C=[FC,x,FC,y]⊤subscript𝑭𝐶superscriptsubscript𝐹𝐶𝑥subscript𝐹𝐶𝑦top{\boldsymbol{F}}_{C}=[F_{C,x},F_{C,y}]^{\top}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, respectively. Furthermore, let 𝑭S:=[0,−m⁢g]⊤assignsubscript𝑭𝑆superscript0𝑚𝑔top{\boldsymbol{F}}_{S}:=[0,-mg]^{\top}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT := [ 0 , - italic_m italic_g ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Note also that the direction of rotation is positive (i.e., counterclockwise) on Figure 7.

The beam is in equilibrium if and only if the resultant force is zero and the resultant moment of the force system that acts on the beam is equal to zero for a given point of the plane. Consequently, the beam is in equilibrium if and only if the resultant force is

(3.1) 𝑭A+𝑭C+𝑭S=𝟎,subscript𝑭𝐴subscript𝑭𝐶subscript𝑭𝑆0\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{F}}_{A}+{\boldsymbol{F}}_{C}+{\boldsymbol{F}}_{S}={% \boldsymbol{0}},bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_S end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = bold_0 ,

and the resultant moment of forces with respect to the point A𝐴Aitalic_A is

(3.2) −m⁢g⋅12+FC,y⁢(12+ξ)=0.⋅𝑚𝑔12subscript𝐹𝐶𝑦12𝜉0\displaystyle-mg\cdot\frac{1}{2}+F_{C,y}\left(\frac{1}{2}+\xi\right)=0.- italic_m italic_g ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + italic_ξ ) = 0 .

Using that the point C𝐶Citalic_C corresponds to a roller support, we have that FC,x=0subscript𝐹𝐶𝑥0F_{C,x}=0italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0, and hence, writing the vectors in the equation (3.1) in coordinate form, we get that

(3.3) [FA,xFA,y]+[0FC,y]+[0−m⁢g]=[00].matrixsubscript𝐹𝐴𝑥subscript𝐹𝐴𝑦matrix0subscript𝐹𝐶𝑦matrix0𝑚𝑔matrix00\displaystyle\begin{bmatrix}F_{A,x}\\ F_{A,y}\\ \end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix}0\\ F_{C,y}\\ \end{bmatrix}+\begin{bmatrix}0\\ -mg\\ \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ 0\\ \end{bmatrix}.[ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] + [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] + [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL - italic_m italic_g end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] .

This shows that FA,x=0subscript𝐹𝐴𝑥0F_{A,x}=0italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 and FA,y+FC,y=m⁢gsubscript𝐹𝐴𝑦subscript𝐹𝐶𝑦𝑚𝑔F_{A,y}+F_{C,y}=mgitalic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_m italic_g. Further, by (3.2), we obtain that

FC,y=m⁢g2⁢(12+ξ)=m⁢g⋅12⁢ξ+1,subscript𝐹𝐶𝑦𝑚𝑔212𝜉⋅𝑚𝑔12𝜉1F_{C,y}=\frac{mg}{2\left(\frac{1}{2}+\xi\right)}=mg\cdot\frac{1}{2\xi+1},italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_m italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG + italic_ξ ) end_ARG = italic_m italic_g ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_ξ + 1 end_ARG ,

and hence

FA,y=m⁢g−FC,y=m⁢g−m⁢g2⁢ξ+1=m⁢g⋅2⁢ξ2⁢ξ+1.subscript𝐹𝐴𝑦𝑚𝑔subscript𝐹𝐶𝑦𝑚𝑔𝑚𝑔2𝜉1⋅𝑚𝑔2𝜉2𝜉1F_{A,y}=mg-F_{C,y}=mg-\frac{mg}{2\xi+1}=mg\cdot\frac{2\xi}{2\xi+1}.italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_m italic_g - italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_m italic_g - divide start_ARG italic_m italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_ξ + 1 end_ARG = italic_m italic_g ⋅ divide start_ARG 2 italic_ξ end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_ξ + 1 end_ARG .

Consequently, we have that

(3.4) 𝑭A=[0m⁢g⋅2⁢ξ2⁢ξ+1]and𝑭C=[0m⁢g⋅12⁢ξ+1].formulae-sequencesubscript𝑭𝐴matrix0⋅𝑚𝑔2𝜉2𝜉1andsubscript𝑭𝐶matrix0⋅𝑚𝑔12𝜉1\displaystyle{\boldsymbol{F}}_{A}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ mg\cdot\frac{2\xi}{2\xi+1}\\ \end{bmatrix}\qquad\text{and}\qquad{\boldsymbol{F}}_{C}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ mg\cdot\frac{1}{2\xi+1}\\ \end{bmatrix}.bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_m italic_g ⋅ divide start_ARG 2 italic_ξ end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_ξ + 1 end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] and bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_m italic_g ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_ξ + 1 end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] .

Therefore, the expected values of the reaction forces at the points A𝐴Aitalic_A and C𝐶Citalic_C take the following forms:

𝔼⁡(𝑭A)=[0m⁢g⁢𝔼⁡(2⁢ξ2⁢ξ+1)]=[0m⁢g⁢(1−ln⁡(2))],𝔼subscript𝑭𝐴matrix0𝑚𝑔𝔼2𝜉2𝜉1matrix0𝑚𝑔12\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}({\boldsymbol{F}}_{A})=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ mg\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left(\frac{2\xi}{2\xi+1}\right)\\ \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ mg(1-\ln(2))\\ \end{bmatrix},blackboard_E ( bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_m italic_g blackboard_E ( divide start_ARG 2 italic_ξ end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_ξ + 1 end_ARG ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_m italic_g ( 1 - roman_ln ( 2 ) ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] ,

and

𝔼⁡(𝑭C)=[0m⁢g⁢𝔼⁡(12⁢ξ+1)]=[0m⁢g⁢ln⁡(2)],𝔼subscript𝑭𝐶matrix0𝑚𝑔𝔼12𝜉1matrix0𝑚𝑔2\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}({\boldsymbol{F}}_{C})=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ mg\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left(\frac{1}{2\xi+1}\right)\\ \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ mg\ln(2)\\ \end{bmatrix},blackboard_E ( bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_m italic_g blackboard_E ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_ξ + 1 end_ARG ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL italic_m italic_g roman_ln ( 2 ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] ,

since

𝔼⁡(12⁢ξ+1)=∫01/212⁢x+1⋅2⁢dx=ln⁡(2)−ln⁡(1)=ln⁡(2),𝔼12𝜉1superscriptsubscript012⋅12𝑥12differential-d𝑥212\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left(\frac{1}{2\xi+1}\right)=\int_{0}^{% 1/2}\frac{1}{2x+1}\cdot 2\,\mathrm{d}x=\ln(2)-\ln(1)=\ln(2),blackboard_E ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_ξ + 1 end_ARG ) = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 1 / 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_x + 1 end_ARG ⋅ 2 roman_d italic_x = roman_ln ( 2 ) - roman_ln ( 1 ) = roman_ln ( 2 ) ,
𝔼⁡(2⁢ξ2⁢ξ+1)=1−𝔼⁡(12⁢ξ+1)=1−ln⁡(2),𝔼2𝜉2𝜉11𝔼12𝜉112\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left(\frac{2\xi}{2\xi+1}\right)=1-% \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\left(\frac{1}{2\xi+1}\right)=1-\ln(2),blackboard_E ( divide start_ARG 2 italic_ξ end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_ξ + 1 end_ARG ) = 1 - blackboard_E ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_ξ + 1 end_ARG ) = 1 - roman_ln ( 2 ) ,

where we used Newton-Leibniz formula and that a primitive function of the function [0,12]∋x↦2/(2⁢x+1)contains012𝑥maps-to22𝑥1[0,\frac{1}{2}]\ni x\mapsto 2/(2x+1)[ 0 , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ] ∋ italic_x ↦ 2 / ( 2 italic_x + 1 ) is [0,12]∋x↦ln⁡(2⁢x+1)contains012𝑥maps-to2𝑥1[0,\frac{1}{2}]\ni x\mapsto\ln(2x+1)[ 0 , divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ] ∋ italic_x ↦ roman_ln ( 2 italic_x + 1 ).

(ii). Similarly to the solution of part (i) (formally replacing ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ by 1414\frac{1}{4}divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG in the formula (3.4)), we get that

𝑭A=[0m⁢g3]and𝑭C=[02⁢m⁢g3].formulae-sequencesubscript𝑭𝐴matrix0𝑚𝑔3andsubscript𝑭𝐶matrix02𝑚𝑔3{\boldsymbol{F}}_{A}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ \frac{mg}{3}\\ \end{bmatrix}\qquad\text{and}\qquad{\boldsymbol{F}}_{C}=\begin{bmatrix}0\\ \frac{2mg}{3}\\ \end{bmatrix}.bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG italic_m italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] and bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG 2 italic_m italic_g end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] .

Since 13≠1−ln⁡(2)1312\frac{1}{3}\neq 1-\ln(2)divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ≠ 1 - roman_ln ( 2 ) and 23≠ln⁡(2)232\frac{2}{3}\neq\ln(2)divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG ≠ roman_ln ( 2 ), the reaction forces above are not equal to the expected reaction forces calculated in the solution of part (ii). This is not a contradiction, since 𝔼⁡(12⁢ξ+1)≠1𝔼⁡(2⁢ξ+1)=12⋅14+1=23𝔼12𝜉11𝔼2𝜉11⋅214123\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\frac{1}{2\xi+1})\neq\frac{1}{\operatorname{\mathbb{% E}}(2\xi+1)}=\frac{1}{2\cdot\frac{1}{4}+1}=\frac{2}{3}blackboard_E ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 italic_ξ + 1 end_ARG ) ≠ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG blackboard_E ( 2 italic_ξ + 1 ) end_ARG = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG + 1 end_ARG = divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG. □□\Box□

3.3 Exercise.

The plate with the dimensions given in Figure 8 is fixed by means of a pin support at point A𝐴Aitalic_A and a rope at point B𝐵Bitalic_B, and is subjected to concentrated forces 𝑭1subscript𝑭1{\boldsymbol{F}}_{1}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝑭2subscript𝑭2{\boldsymbol{F}}_{2}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively. Assume that the mass of the plate can be neglected, and the magnitude of the forces 𝑭1subscript𝑭1{\boldsymbol{F}}_{1}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝑭2subscript𝑭2{\boldsymbol{F}}_{2}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is 300300300\,300N and 100100100\,100N, respectively. Further, we suppose that the distribution of b𝑏bitalic_b is uniform distribution on the interval (0⁢m,3⁢m)0m3m(0\,\mathrm{m},\sqrt{3}\,\mathrm{m})( 0 roman_m , square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG roman_m ).

  • (i)

    What is the distribution of the rope force at point B𝐵Bitalic_B?

  • (ii)

    What is the probability that the magnitude of the rope force at point B𝐵Bitalic_B is in the interval [400⁢3⁢N,400⁢3+100⁢N]4003N4003100N\left[400\sqrt{3}\,\mathrm{N},400\sqrt{3}+100\,\mathrm{N}\right][ 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG roman_N , 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG + 100 roman_N ]?

  • (iii)

    What is the expected value of the magnitude of the rope force at point B𝐵Bitalic_B?

  • (iv)

    What is the expected value of the force at point A𝐴Aitalic_A?

Solution. Let us denote by 𝑭Asubscript𝑭𝐴{\boldsymbol{F}}_{A}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝑭Bsubscript𝑭𝐵{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT the forces at the points A𝐴Aitalic_A and B𝐵Bitalic_B, respectively. In part (i) we need to determine the distribution of ‖𝑭B‖normsubscript𝑭𝐵\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥; in part (ii) the probability ℙ⁡(‖𝑭B‖∈(400⁢3,400⁢3+100))ℙnormsubscript𝑭𝐵40034003100\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|\in(400\sqrt{3},400\sqrt{3}+% 100))blackboard_P ( ∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ∈ ( 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG , 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG + 100 ) ); in part (iii) the expected value of ‖𝑭B‖normsubscript𝑭𝐵\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥; and in part (iv) the expected value of 𝑭Asubscript𝑭𝐴{\boldsymbol{F}}_{A}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Recall that the coordinates of a vector 𝒗𝒗{\boldsymbol{v}}bold_italic_v in the (x,y)𝑥𝑦(x,y)( italic_x , italic_y )-plane are denoted by vxsubscript𝑣𝑥v_{x}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and vysubscript𝑣𝑦v_{y}italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, respectively, i.e., 𝒗=(vx,vy)𝒗subscript𝑣𝑥subscript𝑣𝑦{\boldsymbol{v}}=(v_{x},v_{y})bold_italic_v = ( italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_v start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ). Accordingly, we have 𝑭1=[F1,x,F1,y]⊤subscript𝑭1superscriptsubscript𝐹1𝑥subscript𝐹1𝑦top{\boldsymbol{F}}_{1}=[F_{1,x},F_{1,y}]^{\top}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, 𝑭2=[F2,x,F2,y]⊤subscript𝑭2superscriptsubscript𝐹2𝑥subscript𝐹2𝑦top{\boldsymbol{F}}_{2}=[F_{2,x},F_{2,y}]^{\top}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, 𝑭A=[FA,x,FA,y]⊤subscript𝑭𝐴superscriptsubscript𝐹𝐴𝑥subscript𝐹𝐴𝑦top{\boldsymbol{F}}_{A}=[F_{A,x},F_{A,y}]^{\top}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and 𝑭B=[FB,x,FB,y]⊤subscript𝑭𝐵superscriptsubscript𝐹𝐵𝑥subscript𝐹𝐵𝑦top{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}=[F_{B,x},F_{B,y}]^{\top}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = [ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ] start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ⊤ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We have ‖𝑭1‖=300normsubscript𝑭1300\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{1}\|=300∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ = 300, ‖𝑭2‖=100normsubscript𝑭2100\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{2}\|=100∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ = 100, and

F1,x=−‖𝑭1‖⋅sin⁡(30360⋅2⁢π)=−300⋅12=−150,subscript𝐹1𝑥⋅normsubscript𝑭1⋅303602𝜋⋅30012150\displaystyle F_{1,x}=-\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{1}\|\cdot\sin\left(\frac{30}{360}% \cdot 2\pi\right)=-300\cdot\frac{1}{2}=-150,italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - ∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ⋅ roman_sin ( divide start_ARG 30 end_ARG start_ARG 360 end_ARG ⋅ 2 italic_π ) = - 300 ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG = - 150 ,
F1,y=−‖𝑭1‖⋅cos⁡(30360⋅2⁢π)=−300⋅32=−150⁢3,subscript𝐹1𝑦⋅normsubscript𝑭1⋅303602𝜋⋅300321503\displaystyle F_{1,y}=-\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{1}\|\cdot\cos\left(\frac{30}{360}% \cdot 2\pi\right)=-300\cdot\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}=-150\sqrt{3},italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = - ∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ⋅ roman_cos ( divide start_ARG 30 end_ARG start_ARG 360 end_ARG ⋅ 2 italic_π ) = - 300 ⋅ divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG = - 150 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG ,

We take the direction of rotation as positive (i.e., counterclockwise) on Figure 8. Hence the moments M1𝐴𝐴subscript𝑀1\underset{A}{M_{1}}underitalic_A start_ARG italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG, M2𝐴𝐴subscript𝑀2\underset{A}{M_{2}}underitalic_A start_ARG italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG and MB𝐴𝐴subscript𝑀𝐵\underset{A}{M_{B}}underitalic_A start_ARG italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG of the forces 𝑭1subscript𝑭1{\boldsymbol{F}}_{1}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, 𝑭2subscript𝑭2{\boldsymbol{F}}_{2}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and 𝑭Bsubscript𝑭𝐵{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT with respect to the point A𝐴Aitalic_A are

M1𝐴:=‖𝑭1‖⋅cos⁡(30360⋅2⁢π)⋅(2+b)=300⁢32⁢(2+b)=150⁢3⁢(2+b),assign𝐴subscript𝑀1⋅normsubscript𝑭1⋅303602𝜋2𝑏300322𝑏15032𝑏\displaystyle\underset{A}{M_{1}}:=\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{1}\|\cdot\cos\left(\frac% {30}{360}\cdot 2\pi\right)\cdot(2+b)=300\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}(2+b)=150\sqrt{3}(2+% b),underitalic_A start_ARG italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG := ∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ⋅ roman_cos ( divide start_ARG 30 end_ARG start_ARG 360 end_ARG ⋅ 2 italic_π ) ⋅ ( 2 + italic_b ) = 300 divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ( 2 + italic_b ) = 150 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG ( 2 + italic_b ) ,
