MB𝐴:=−‖𝑭B‖⋅cos⁡(60360⋅2⁢π)⋅1.5=−‖𝑭B‖⋅12⋅1.5=−34⁢‖𝑭B‖.assign𝐴subscript𝑀𝐵⋅normsubscript𝑭𝐵⋅603602𝜋1.5⋅normsubscript𝑭𝐵121.534normsubscript𝑭𝐵\displaystyle\underset{A}{M_{B}}:=-\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|\cdot\cos\left(% \frac{60}{360}\cdot 2\pi\right)\cdot 1.5=-\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|\cdot\frac{1% }{2}\cdot 1.5=-\frac{3}{4}\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|.underitalic_A start_ARG italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG := - ∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ⋅ roman_cos ( divide start_ARG 60 end_ARG start_ARG 360 end_ARG ⋅ 2 italic_π ) ⋅ 1.5 = - ∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ⋅ divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ⋅ 1.5 = - divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ .

Since the plate is balanced, the equilibrium of forces in the directions x𝑥xitalic_x and y𝑦yitalic_y and that of the moment of forces with respect to the point A𝐴Aitalic_A are as follows:

FA,x+FB,x+F1,x+F2,x=0,subscript𝐹𝐴𝑥subscript𝐹𝐵𝑥subscript𝐹1𝑥subscript𝐹2𝑥0\displaystyle F_{A,x}+F_{B,x}+F_{1,x}+F_{2,x}=0,italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 ,
FA,y+FB,y+F1,y+F2,y=0,subscript𝐹𝐴𝑦subscript𝐹𝐵𝑦subscript𝐹1𝑦subscript𝐹2𝑦0\displaystyle F_{A,y}+F_{B,y}+F_{1,y}+F_{2,y}=0,italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 ,
MB𝐴+M1𝐴+M2𝐴=0.𝐴subscript𝑀𝐵𝐴subscript𝑀1𝐴subscript𝑀20\displaystyle\underset{A}{M_{B}}+\underset{A}{M_{1}}+\underset{A}{M_{2}}=0.underitalic_A start_ARG italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + underitalic_A start_ARG italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG + underitalic_A start_ARG italic_M start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG = 0 .

This system of equations takes the form

FA,x+12⁢‖𝑭B‖subscript𝐹𝐴𝑥12normsubscript𝑭𝐵\displaystyle F_{A,x}+\frac{1}{2}\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ =150+50⁢2,absent150502\displaystyle=150+50\sqrt{2},= 150 + 50 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG ,
FA,y+32⁢‖𝑭B‖subscript𝐹𝐴𝑦32normsubscript𝑭𝐵\displaystyle F_{A,y}+\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG ∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ =150⁢3−50⁢2,absent1503502\displaystyle=150\sqrt{3}-50\sqrt{2},= 150 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - 50 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG ,
−34⁢‖𝑭B‖34normsubscript𝑭𝐵\displaystyle-\frac{3}{4}\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|- divide start_ARG 3 end_ARG start_ARG 4 end_ARG ∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ =−150⁢3⁢(2+b)+25⁢2.absent15032𝑏252\displaystyle=-150\sqrt{3}(2+b)+25\sqrt{2}.= - 150 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG ( 2 + italic_b ) + 25 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG .

This is a system of linear equations in the variables FA,xsubscript𝐹𝐴𝑥F_{A,x}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, FA,ysubscript𝐹𝐴𝑦F_{A,y}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and ‖𝑭B‖normsubscript𝑭𝐵\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥. It follows from the last equation that

‖𝑭B‖=400⁢3−1003⁢2+200⁢3⁢b.normsubscript𝑭𝐵4003100322003𝑏\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|=400\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}+200\sqrt{3}b.∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ = 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 200 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG italic_b .

Substituting the value of ‖𝑭B‖normsubscript𝑭𝐵\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ to the second equation, we get that

FA,y=150⁢3−50⁢2−600+50⁢63−300⁢b.subscript𝐹𝐴𝑦15035026005063300𝑏F_{A,y}=150\sqrt{3}-50\sqrt{2}-600+50\frac{\sqrt{6}}{3}-300b.italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 150 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - 50 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG - 600 + 50 divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 6 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG - 300 italic_b .

By substituting the value of ‖𝑭B‖normsubscript𝑭𝐵\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ to the first equation, we have

FA,x=150+2003⁢2−200⁢3−100⁢3⁢b.subscript𝐹𝐴𝑥1502003220031003𝑏F_{A,x}=150+\frac{200}{3}\sqrt{2}-200\sqrt{3}-100\sqrt{3}b.italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 150 + divide start_ARG 200 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG - 200 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - 100 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG italic_b .

(i). Since b𝑏bitalic_b has a uniform distribution on the interval (0,3)03(0,\sqrt{3})( 0 , square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG ), its cumulative distribution function takes the form

ℙ⁡(b<x)={0if x⩽0,x3if x∈(0,3),1if x⩾3.ℙ𝑏𝑥cases0if x⩽0𝑥3if x∈(0,3)1if x⩾3\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(b<x)=\begin{cases}0&\text{if $x\leqslant 0$},\\ \frac{x}{\sqrt{3}}&\text{if $x\in(0,\sqrt{3})$},\\ 1&\text{if $x\geqslant\sqrt{3}$}.\end{cases}blackboard_P ( italic_b < italic_x ) = { start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x ⩽ 0 , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG italic_x end_ARG start_ARG square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_ARG end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x ∈ ( 0 , square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG ) , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x ⩾ square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG . end_CELL end_ROW

Hence the cumulative distribution function of ‖𝑭B‖normsubscript𝑭𝐵\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ can be written as

ℙ⁡(‖𝑭B‖<x)=ℙ⁡(400⁢3−1003⁢2+200⁢3⁢b<x)ℙnormsubscript𝑭𝐵𝑥ℙ4003100322003𝑏𝑥\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|<x)=% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(400\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}+200\sqrt{3}b<% x\right)blackboard_P ( ∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ < italic_x ) = blackboard_P ( 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 200 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG italic_b < italic_x )
=ℙ⁡(b<x−400⁢3+1003⁢2200⁢3)absentℙ𝑏𝑥4003100322003\displaystyle=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(b<\frac{x-400\sqrt{3}+\frac{100}{% 3}\sqrt{2}}{200\sqrt{3}}\right)= blackboard_P ( italic_b < divide start_ARG italic_x - 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG + divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 200 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_ARG )
={0if x⩽400⁢3+1003⁢2,x−400⁢3+1003⁢2200⁢3if x∈(400⁢3−1003⁢2,400⁢3−1003⁢2+600),1if x⩾400⁢3−1003⁢2+600.absentcases0if x⩽400⁢3+1003⁢2,𝑥4003100322003if x∈(400⁢3−1003⁢2,400⁢3−1003⁢2+600),1if x⩾400⁢3−1003⁢2+600.\displaystyle=\begin{cases}0&\text{if $x\leqslant 400\sqrt{3}+\frac{100}{3}% \sqrt{2}$,}\\ \frac{x-400\sqrt{3}+\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}}{200\sqrt{3}}&\text{if $x\in\left(40% 0\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2},400\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}+600\right)$,% }\\ 1&\text{if $x\geqslant 400\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}+600$.}\end{cases}= { start_ROW start_CELL 0 end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x ⩽ 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG + divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG italic_x - 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG + divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 200 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_ARG end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x ∈ ( 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG , 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 600 ) , end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 1 end_CELL start_CELL if italic_x ⩾ 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 600 . end_CELL end_ROW

Consequently, ‖𝑭B‖normsubscript𝑭𝐵\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ has a uniform distribution on the interval

(400⁢3−1003⁢2,400⁢3−1003⁢2+600).400310032400310032600\left(400\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2},400\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}+600% \right).( 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG , 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 600 ) .

(ii). Using the results in the solution of part (i), we get that

ℙ⁡(‖𝑭B‖∈[400⁢3,400⁢3+100])ℙnormsubscript𝑭𝐵40034003100\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}\left(\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|\in\left[4% 00\sqrt{3},400\sqrt{3}+100\right]\right)blackboard_P ( ∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ ∈ [ 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG , 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG + 100 ] )
=400⁢3+100−400⁢3+1003⁢2600−400⁢3−400⁢3+1003⁢2600=16.absent4003100400310032600400340031003260016\displaystyle=\frac{400\sqrt{3}+100-400\sqrt{3}+\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}}{600}-% \frac{400\sqrt{3}-400\sqrt{3}+\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}}{600}=\frac{1}{6}.= divide start_ARG 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG + 100 - 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG + divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 600 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG + divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 600 end_ARG = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 6 end_ARG .

We note that this probability can be calculated using geometric probabilities as well. Namely, the length of the interval [400⁢3,400⁢3+100]40034003100\left[400\sqrt{3},400\sqrt{3}+100\right][ 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG , 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG + 100 ] and (400⁢3−1003⁢2,400⁢3−1003⁢2+600)400310032400310032600\left(400\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2},400\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}+600\right)( 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG , 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 600 ) is 100100100100 and 600600600600, respectively, and hence the probability in question is 100600=1610060016\frac{100}{600}=\frac{1}{6}divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 600 end_ARG = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 6 end_ARG.

(iii). The expected value of ‖𝑭B‖normsubscript𝑭𝐵\|{\boldsymbol{F}}_{B}\|∥ bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_B end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∥ is

400⁢3−1003⁢2+400⁢3−1003⁢2+6002=400⁢3−1003⁢2+300≈945.7.4003100324003100326002400310032300945.7\dfrac{400\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}+400\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}+600% }{2}=400\sqrt{3}-\frac{100}{3}\sqrt{2}+300\approx 945.7.divide start_ARG 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 600 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG = 400 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - divide start_ARG 100 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 300 ≈ 945.7 .

(iv). The expected value of 𝑭Asubscript𝑭𝐴{\boldsymbol{F}}_{A}bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is

𝔼⁡(𝑭A)𝔼subscript𝑭𝐴\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}({\boldsymbol{F}}_{A})blackboard_E ( bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) =[𝔼⁡(FA,x)𝔼⁡(FA,y)]=[𝔼⁡(150+2003⁢2−200⁢3−100⁢3⁢b)𝔼⁡(150⁢3−50⁢2−600+50⁢63−300⁢b)]absentmatrix𝔼subscript𝐹𝐴𝑥𝔼subscript𝐹𝐴𝑦matrix𝔼1502003220031003𝑏𝔼15035026005063300𝑏\displaystyle=\begin{bmatrix}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(F_{A,x})\\ \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(F_{A,y})\\ \end{bmatrix}=\begin{bmatrix}\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\big{(}150+\frac{200}{3}% \sqrt{2}-200\sqrt{3}-100\sqrt{3}b\big{)}\\ \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}\big{(}150\sqrt{3}-50\sqrt{2}-600+50\frac{\sqrt{6}}{3% }-300b\big{)}\\ \end{bmatrix}= [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL blackboard_E ( italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL blackboard_E ( italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A , italic_y end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL blackboard_E ( 150 + divide start_ARG 200 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG - 200 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - 100 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG italic_b ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL blackboard_E ( 150 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - 50 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG - 600 + 50 divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 6 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG - 300 italic_b ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ]
=[150+2003⁢2−200⁢3−100⁢3⁢𝔼⁡(b)150⁢3−50⁢2−600+50⁢63−300⁢𝔼⁡(b)].absentmatrix1502003220031003𝔼𝑏15035026005063300𝔼𝑏\displaystyle=\begin{bmatrix}150+\frac{200}{3}\sqrt{2}-200\sqrt{3}-100\sqrt{3}% \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(b)\\ 150\sqrt{3}-50\sqrt{2}-600+50\frac{\sqrt{6}}{3}-300\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(b% )\\ \end{bmatrix}.= [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL 150 + divide start_ARG 200 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG - 200 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - 100 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG blackboard_E ( italic_b ) end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL 150 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG - 50 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG - 600 + 50 divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 6 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG - 300 blackboard_E ( italic_b ) end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] .

Using that 𝔼⁡(b)=32𝔼𝑏32\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(b)=\frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}blackboard_E ( italic_b ) = divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG, we have that

𝔼⁡(𝑭A)=[2003⁢2−200⁢3−600−50⁢2+50⁢63]≈[−252.1−629.9].𝔼subscript𝑭𝐴matrix2003220036005025063matrix252.1629.9\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}({\boldsymbol{F}}_{A})=\begin{bmatrix}% \frac{200}{3}\sqrt{2}-200\sqrt{3}\\ -600-50\sqrt{2}+50\frac{\sqrt{6}}{3}\\ \end{bmatrix}\approx\begin{bmatrix}-252.1\\ -629.9\\ \end{bmatrix}.blackboard_E ( bold_italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL divide start_ARG 200 end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG - 200 square-root start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL - 600 - 50 square-root start_ARG 2 end_ARG + 50 divide start_ARG square-root start_ARG 6 end_ARG end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] ≈ [ start_ARG start_ROW start_CELL - 252.1 end_CELL end_ROW start_ROW start_CELL - 629.9 end_CELL end_ROW end_ARG ] .

□□\Box□

4 Concluding remarks

Our method for incorporating a stochastic point of view into physics exercises of mathematics education may be used in several different ways by high school students and teachers and by first-year university students. The core of the method is the randomization of some inputs, the system model used does not differ from what we would use in the deterministic approach. We demonstrate our method of randomization of some inputs by considering exercises from the theory of projectile motion and statics. Students may be asked to create similar exercises, for other fields of physics as well. Our stochastic perspective can help the students recognize the fact that many phenomena in our daily lives have a random nature, and therefore it can be useful to get in touch with stochastic thinking and tools in order to be able to understand these phenomena much better. Computer simulations using Monte Carlo methods might also be assigned to our elaborate examples in order to confirm the solutions empirically.

Appendices

Appendix A Basic knowledge of probability

In this appendix, we recall some of the notations, conventions, concepts and results of probability theory that are used in solving the exercises.

In all of the paper, (Ω,𝒜,ℙ)Ω𝒜ℙ(\Omega,{\mathcal{A}},\operatorname{\mathbb{P}})( roman_Ω , caligraphic_A , blackboard_P ) denotes a probability space, where ΩΩ\Omegaroman_Ω is called sample space. A mapping ξ:Ω→ℝ:𝜉→Ωℝ\xi:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}italic_ξ : roman_Ω → blackboard_R is called a random variable if {ω∈Ω:ξ⁢(ω)<x}∈𝒜conditional-set𝜔Ω𝜉𝜔𝑥𝒜\{\omega\in\Omega:\xi(\omega)<x\}\in{\mathcal{A}}{ italic_ω ∈ roman_Ω : italic_ξ ( italic_ω ) < italic_x } ∈ caligraphic_A for all x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R}italic_x ∈ blackboard_R. By a 2222-dimensional random vector, we mean a mapping (ξ,η):Ω→ℝ2:𝜉𝜂→Ωsuperscriptℝ2(\xi,\eta):\Omega\to\mathbb{R}^{2}( italic_ξ , italic_η ) : roman_Ω → blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, where ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ and η𝜂\etaitalic_η are (1-dimensional) random variables. Given a random variable ξ:Ω→ℝ:𝜉→Ωℝ\xi:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}italic_ξ : roman_Ω → blackboard_R and a real number x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R}italic_x ∈ blackboard_R, we use the notational conventions {ξ<x}:={ω∈Ω:ξ⁢(ω)<x}assign𝜉𝑥conditional-set𝜔Ω𝜉𝜔𝑥\{\xi<x\}:=\{\omega\in\Omega:\xi(\omega)<x\}{ italic_ξ < italic_x } := { italic_ω ∈ roman_Ω : italic_ξ ( italic_ω ) < italic_x }, and accordingly ℙ⁡(ξ<x):=ℙ⁡({ξ<x})assignℙ𝜉𝑥ℙ𝜉𝑥\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi<x):=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\{\xi<x\})blackboard_P ( italic_ξ < italic_x ) := blackboard_P ( { italic_ξ < italic_x } ).

Given events A,B∈𝒜𝐴𝐵𝒜A,B\in{\mathcal{A}}italic_A , italic_B ∈ caligraphic_A such that ℙ⁡(B)>0ℙ𝐵0\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(B)>0blackboard_P ( italic_B ) > 0, the conditional probability of A𝐴Aitalic_A given B𝐵Bitalic_B is defined by ℙ⁡(A∩B)ℙ⁡(B)ℙ𝐴𝐵ℙ𝐵\frac{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A\cap B)}{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(B)}divide start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_A ∩ italic_B ) end_ARG start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_B ) end_ARG, and is denoted by ℙ⁡(A|B)ℙconditional𝐴𝐵\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A\,|\,B)blackboard_P ( italic_A | italic_B ). Given events A,B∈𝒜𝐴𝐵𝒜A,B\in{\mathcal{A}}italic_A , italic_B ∈ caligraphic_A such that ℙ⁡(A)∈(0,1)ℙ𝐴01\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A)\in(0,1)blackboard_P ( italic_A ) ∈ ( 0 , 1 ) and ℙ⁡(B)>0ℙ𝐵0\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(B)>0blackboard_P ( italic_B ) > 0, Bayes’s theorem states that

(A.1) ℙ⁡(A|B)=ℙ⁡(B|A)⁢ℙ⁡(A)ℙ⁡(B|A)⁢ℙ⁡(A)+ℙ⁡(B|Ω∖A)⁢ℙ⁡(Ω∖A).ℙconditional𝐴𝐵ℙconditional𝐵𝐴ℙ𝐴ℙconditional𝐵𝐴ℙ𝐴ℙconditional𝐵Ω𝐴ℙΩ𝐴\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A\,|\,B)=\frac{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}% }(B\,|\,A)\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A)}{\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(B\,|\,A)% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A)+\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(B\,|\,\Omega\setminus A% )\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\Omega\setminus A)}.blackboard_P ( italic_A | italic_B ) = divide start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_B | italic_A ) blackboard_P ( italic_A ) end_ARG start_ARG blackboard_P ( italic_B | italic_A ) blackboard_P ( italic_A ) + blackboard_P ( italic_B | roman_Ω ∖ italic_A ) blackboard_P ( roman_Ω ∖ italic_A ) end_ARG .

In some cases, we calculate the probability of an event using the method of geometric probabilities. In this case, the underlying probability space is chosen as a (Borel) subset S𝑆Sitalic_S of ℝ2superscriptℝ2\mathbb{R}^{2}blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT furnished with the sigma-algebra ℬ⁢(S)ℬ𝑆{\mathcal{B}}(S)caligraphic_B ( italic_S ) generated by all of the open subsets of S𝑆Sitalic_S (i.e., with the Borel sigma-algebra of S𝑆Sitalic_S), and, for all A∈ℬ⁢(S)𝐴ℬ𝑆A\in{\mathcal{B}}(S)italic_A ∈ caligraphic_B ( italic_S ), the probability ℙ⁡(A)ℙ𝐴\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(A)blackboard_P ( italic_A ) of A𝐴Aitalic_A is defined as the fraction of the area (2222-dimensional Lebesgue measure) of A𝐴Aitalic_A and that of S𝑆Sitalic_S, where we suppose that the area of S𝑆Sitalic_S is positive.

The cumulative distribution function of a random variable ξ:Ω→ℝ:𝜉→Ωℝ\xi:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}italic_ξ : roman_Ω → blackboard_R is defined by Fξ:ℝ→ℝ:subscript𝐹𝜉→ℝℝF_{\xi}:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : blackboard_R → blackboard_R, Fξ⁢(x):=ℙ⁡(ξ<x)assignsubscript𝐹𝜉𝑥ℙ𝜉𝑥F_{\xi}(x):=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi<x)italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) := blackboard_P ( italic_ξ < italic_x ), x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R}italic_x ∈ blackboard_R. A random variable is called discrete if its range ξ⁢(Ω)𝜉Ω\xi(\Omega)italic_ξ ( roman_Ω ) is countable. By the (probability) distribution of a discrete random variable ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ having range ξ(Ω)=:{xi:i∈ℕ}\xi(\Omega)=:\{x_{i}:i\in\mathbb{N}\}italic_ξ ( roman_Ω ) = : { italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_i ∈ blackboard_N }, we mean the sequence (ℙ⁡(ξ=xi))i∈ℕsubscriptℙ𝜉subscript𝑥𝑖𝑖ℕ(\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=x_{i}))_{i\in\mathbb{N}}( blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ blackboard_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. A random variable ξ:Ω→ℝ:𝜉→Ωℝ\xi:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}italic_ξ : roman_Ω → blackboard_R is called absolutely continuous if there exists a (Borel measurable) non-negative function fξ:ℝ→ℝ:subscript𝑓𝜉→ℝℝf_{\xi}:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : blackboard_R → blackboard_R such that Fξ⁢(x)=∫−∞xfξ⁢(t)⁢dtsubscript𝐹𝜉𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑓𝜉𝑡differential-d𝑡F_{\xi}(x)=\int_{-\infty}^{x}f_{\xi}(t)\,\mathrm{d}titalic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) roman_d italic_t, x∈ℝ𝑥ℝx\in\mathbb{R}italic_x ∈ blackboard_R. The expected value (expectation) and of a discrete random variable ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ having range ξ(Ω)=:{xi:i∈ℕ}\xi(\Omega)=:\{x_{i}:i\in\mathbb{N}\}italic_ξ ( roman_Ω ) = : { italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : italic_i ∈ blackboard_N } is defined by 𝔼⁡(ξ):=∑i=1∞xi⁢ℙ⁡(ξ=xi)assign𝔼𝜉superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑥𝑖ℙ𝜉subscript𝑥𝑖\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi):=\sum_{i=1}^{\infty}x_{i}\operatorname{\mathbb{% P}}(\xi=x_{i})blackboard_E ( italic_ξ ) := ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), provided that ∑i=1∞|xi|⁢ℙ⁡(ξ=xi)<∞superscriptsubscript𝑖1subscript𝑥𝑖ℙ𝜉subscript𝑥𝑖\sum_{i=1}^{\infty}|x_{i}|\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi=x_{i})<\infty∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | blackboard_P ( italic_ξ = italic_x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) < ∞. The expected value (expectation) of an absolutely continuous random variable ξ:Ω→ℝ:𝜉→Ωℝ\xi:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}italic_ξ : roman_Ω → blackboard_R with a density function fξsubscript𝑓𝜉f_{\xi}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is defined by 𝔼⁡(ξ):=∫−∞∞x⁢fξ⁢(x)⁢dxassign𝔼𝜉superscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑓𝜉𝑥differential-d𝑥\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi):=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}xf_{\xi}(x)\,\mathrm{d}xblackboard_E ( italic_ξ ) := ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_x italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) roman_d italic_x, provided that ∫−∞∞|x|⁢fξ⁢(x)⁢dx<∞superscriptsubscript𝑥subscript𝑓𝜉𝑥differential-d𝑥\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}|x|f_{\xi}(x)\,\mathrm{d}x<\infty∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_x | italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) roman_d italic_x < ∞. The variance and standard deviation of a random variable ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ is defined by 𝔻2⁡(ξ):=𝔼⁡((ξ−𝔼⁡(ξ))2)assignsuperscript𝔻2𝜉𝔼superscript𝜉𝔼𝜉2\operatorname{\mathbb{D}}^{2}(\xi):=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}((\xi-% \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi))^{2})blackboard_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ξ ) := blackboard_E ( ( italic_ξ - blackboard_E ( italic_ξ ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) and 𝔻⁡(ξ):=𝔼⁡((ξ−𝔼⁡(ξ))2)assign𝔻𝜉𝔼superscript𝜉𝔼𝜉2\operatorname{\mathbb{D}}(\xi):=\sqrt{\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}((\xi-% \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi))^{2})}blackboard_D ( italic_ξ ) := square-root start_ARG blackboard_E ( ( italic_ξ - blackboard_E ( italic_ξ ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) end_ARG, respectively, provided that 𝔼⁡(ξ2)<∞𝔼superscript𝜉2\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi^{2})<\inftyblackboard_E ( italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) < ∞. It is know that 𝔻2⁡(ξ)=𝔼⁡(ξ2)−(𝔼⁡(ξ))2superscript𝔻2𝜉𝔼superscript𝜉2superscript𝔼𝜉2\operatorname{\mathbb{D}}^{2}(\xi)=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi^{2})-(% \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi))^{2}blackboard_D start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_ξ ) = blackboard_E ( italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - ( blackboard_E ( italic_ξ ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. The relative standard deviation (also known as coefficient of variation) of a positive random variable ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ having finite second moment (i.e., 𝔼⁡(ξ2)<∞𝔼superscript𝜉2\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi^{2})<\inftyblackboard_E ( italic_ξ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) < ∞) is given by RSD⁡(ξ):=𝔻⁡(ξ)/𝔼⁡(ξ)assignRSD𝜉𝔻𝜉𝔼𝜉\operatorname{RSD}(\xi):=\operatorname{\mathbb{D}}(\xi)/\operatorname{\mathbb{% E}}(\xi)roman_RSD ( italic_ξ ) := blackboard_D ( italic_ξ ) / blackboard_E ( italic_ξ ). Roughly speaking, the higher relative standard deviation of a nonnegative random variable ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ, the greater the level of dispersion of the values of ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ around its mean 𝔼⁡(ξ)𝔼𝜉\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi)blackboard_E ( italic_ξ ). If (ξ,η)𝜉𝜂(\xi,\eta)( italic_ξ , italic_η ) is a 2222-dimensional random vector such that 𝔼⁡(ξ)𝔼𝜉\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi)blackboard_E ( italic_ξ ) and 𝔼⁡(η)𝔼𝜂\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\eta)blackboard_E ( italic_η ) are defined, then the expectation vector of (ξ,η)𝜉𝜂(\xi,\eta)( italic_ξ , italic_η ) is given by 𝔼⁡(ξ,η):=(𝔼⁡(ξ),𝔼⁡(η))assign𝔼𝜉𝜂𝔼𝜉𝔼𝜂\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi,\eta):=(\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi),% \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\eta))blackboard_E ( italic_ξ , italic_η ) := ( blackboard_E ( italic_ξ ) , blackboard_E ( italic_η ) ). If ξ:Ω→ℝ:𝜉→Ωℝ\xi:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}italic_ξ : roman_Ω → blackboard_R is a random variable such that 𝔼⁡(ξ)𝔼𝜉\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi)blackboard_E ( italic_ξ ) is defined and a,b∈ℝ𝑎𝑏ℝa,b\in\mathbb{R}italic_a , italic_b ∈ blackboard_R, then 𝔼⁡(a⁢ξ+b)𝔼𝑎𝜉𝑏\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(a\xi+b)blackboard_E ( italic_a italic_ξ + italic_b ) is defined as well and

(A.2) 𝔼⁡(a⁢ξ+b)=a⁢𝔼⁡(ξ)+b.𝔼𝑎𝜉𝑏𝑎𝔼𝜉𝑏\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(a\xi+b)=a\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi)% +b.blackboard_E ( italic_a italic_ξ + italic_b ) = italic_a blackboard_E ( italic_ξ ) + italic_b .

If ξ,η:Ω→ℝ:𝜉𝜂→Ωℝ\xi,\eta:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}italic_ξ , italic_η : roman_Ω → blackboard_R are random variables, then the function Fξ,η:ℝ2→ℝ:subscript𝐹𝜉𝜂→superscriptℝ2ℝF_{\xi,\eta}:\mathbb{R}^{2}\to\mathbb{R}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ , italic_η end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R, Fξ,η⁢(x,y):=ℙ⁡(ξ<x,η<y)assignsubscript𝐹𝜉𝜂𝑥𝑦ℙ𝜉𝑥𝜂𝑦F_{\xi,\eta}(x,y):=\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(\xi<x,\eta<y)italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ , italic_η end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_y ) := blackboard_P ( italic_ξ < italic_x , italic_η < italic_y ), x,y∈ℝ𝑥𝑦ℝx,y\in\mathbb{R}italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_R, is called the joint distribution function of ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ and η𝜂\etaitalic_η. The random variables ξ,η:Ω→ℝ:𝜉𝜂→Ωℝ\xi,\eta:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}italic_ξ , italic_η : roman_Ω → blackboard_R are called independent if Fξ,η⁢(x,y)=Fξ⁢(x)⁢Fη⁢(y)subscript𝐹𝜉𝜂𝑥𝑦subscript𝐹𝜉𝑥subscript𝐹𝜂𝑦F_{\xi,\eta}(x,y)=F_{\xi}(x)F_{\eta}(y)italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ , italic_η end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x , italic_y ) = italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ξ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_x ) italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_η end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_y ), x,y∈ℝ𝑥𝑦ℝx,y\in\mathbb{R}italic_x , italic_y ∈ blackboard_R, i.e., the joint distribution function of ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ and η𝜂\etaitalic_η is the product of the distribution functions of ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ and η𝜂\etaitalic_η. If ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ and η𝜂\etaitalic_η are independent random variables and g,h:ℝ→ℝ:𝑔ℎ→ℝℝg,h:\mathbb{R}\to\mathbb{R}italic_g , italic_h : blackboard_R → blackboard_R are (Borel measurable) functions, then the random variables g⁢(ξ)𝑔𝜉g(\xi)italic_g ( italic_ξ ) and h⁢(η)ℎ𝜂h(\eta)italic_h ( italic_η ) are also independent. If ξ𝜉\xiitalic_ξ and η𝜂\etaitalic_η are independent random variables such that 𝔼⁡(ξ)𝔼𝜉\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi)blackboard_E ( italic_ξ ) and 𝔼⁡(η)𝔼𝜂\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\eta)blackboard_E ( italic_η ) are defined, then 𝔼⁡(ξ⁢η)𝔼𝜉𝜂\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi\eta)blackboard_E ( italic_ξ italic_η ) is defined as well and

(A.3) 𝔼⁡(ξ⁢η)=𝔼⁡(ξ)⁢𝔼⁡(η).𝔼𝜉𝜂𝔼𝜉𝔼𝜂\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi\eta)=\operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\xi)% \operatorname{\mathbb{E}}(\eta).blackboard_E ( italic_ξ italic_η ) = blackboard_E ( italic_ξ ) blackboard_E ( italic_η ) .

Finally, we formulate the law of total expectation that is used in the solution of Exercise 2.1. Let (Ω,𝒜,ℙ)Ω𝒜ℙ(\Omega,\mathcal{A},\operatorname{\mathbb{P}})( roman_Ω , caligraphic_A , blackboard_P ) be a probability space, ξ:Ω→ℝ:𝜉→Ωℝ\xi:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}italic_ξ : roman_Ω → blackboard_R and η:Ω→ℝ:𝜂→Ωℝ\eta:\Omega\to\mathbb{R}italic_η : roman_Ω → blackboard_R are independent random variables such that η𝜂\etaitalic_η is absolutely continuous with a density function fηsubscript𝑓𝜂f_{\eta}italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_η end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Then for any (Borel measurable) function G:ℝ2→ℝ:𝐺→superscriptℝ2ℝG:\mathbb{R}^{2}\to\mathbb{R}italic_G : blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R, we have that

(A.4) ℙ⁡(G⁢(ξ,η)<z)=∫−∞∞ℙ⁡(G⁢(ξ,r)<z)⁢fη⁢(r)⁢dr,z∈ℝ.formulae-sequenceℙ𝐺𝜉𝜂𝑧superscriptsubscriptℙ𝐺𝜉𝑟𝑧subscript𝑓𝜂𝑟differential-d𝑟𝑧ℝ\displaystyle\operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(G(\xi,\eta)<z)=\int_{-\infty}^{\infty}% \operatorname{\mathbb{P}}(G(\xi,r)<z)f_{\eta}(r)\,\mathrm{d}r,\qquad z\in% \mathbb{R}.blackboard_P ( italic_G ( italic_ξ , italic_η ) < italic_z ) = ∫ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT - ∞ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∞ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT blackboard_P ( italic_G ( italic_ξ , italic_r ) < italic_z ) italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_η end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_r ) roman_d italic_r , italic_z ∈ blackboard_R .

Appendix B Basic knowledge of mechanics

In this appendix, we provide some concepts of mechanics used in solving the exercises.

Motion in a homogeneous gravitational field (projectile motion) is discussed in the simplest planar model, assuming that the drag force (air resistance) is negligible. In this case, the only force acting on a point-like object is the constant gravitational force (m⋅g⋅𝑚𝑔m\cdot gitalic_m ⋅ italic_g), and the equation of the motion is a parabola. This type of motion is the superposition of a uniform motion in the horizontal direction and a uniformly accelerated motion (”free fall”) in the vertical direction.

In general, the initial velocity is arbitrary; its two components are the initial velocities in the horizontal and vertical directions. In our examples, only one of the initial velocity components is different from zero. Since the relevant formulas are well known and can be found in high school physics textbooks, we will not list them here. When solving the exercises, we will simply recall and apply them. Here we only mention the book by de Lange and Pierrus [2, Section 7] where one can find several interesting exercises with detailed solutions for two and three dimensional projectile motions.

The following is a list of some basic static concepts used in Section 3. A prismatic beam is a beam with a uniform cross-section throughout. Reaction forces are the forces exerted by the supports on the beam to achieve equilibrium of a force system. Two basic types of supports are used in this paper. The first one is the pinned support, which can resist forces in any direction, but not rotation. It allows the beam to rotate, but not to translate in any direction. In this case the reaction force can be any force in the plane, i.e. its components can be different from zero in any direction. The second one is the roller support which is free to rotate and translate along the surface on which the roller rests. In this case, the reaction force is perpendicular to and away from the surface (in particular, its component parallel to the surface is zero).

The rotating effect of a force with respect to a (fixed) point is described by its moment of force, which is a scalar quantity in planar problems. The convention is that the sign of the moment of force is positive if it rotates counterclockwise in the plane. The magnitude of the moment of a force with respect to a point (point of rotation) is the product of the magnitude of the force and its lever arm, where the lever arm is the distance between the point of rotation and the line of action of the force.

To determine unknown reaction forces in a equilibrium situation of a rigid body in the plane, we can write equilibrium equations for the forces and the moments of forces. One type of the equilibrium equations says that the sum of force vectors is zero. In planar problems it means two scalar equations in two perpendicular directions (e.g. horizontal and vertical). In planar problems, the other type of the equilibrium equations says that the sum of scalar moments of forces with respect to an arbitrary point of the plane is zero. All in all, a rigid body in the plane is in equilibrium if the sum of the force vectors acting on it is zero and the sum of the corresponding scalar moments of forces with respect to an arbitrary point of the plane is zero.
